headline: A floating blimp flown by a Kamikaze pilot named Recruit Co.
pros: WLB is on par with the industry.
cons:
1. Compensation is below market. The company will say over and over "we will never pay like these other big tech companies" while failing to realize that they are literally surrounded by every major tech company in Austin. Ya'll can have the B and C players.
2. Leadership lacks product vision. Indeed is like Kodak milking sales of physical film in the 80s except they don't have a digital camera breakthrough product on the back burner. They have nothing.

headline: Business before People
pros:
- Unlimited PTO WHEN having a good manager

- Nice office/ building in Cap Dock

- Possibility of internal development/promotion every year

- YOU DAY (1 day off offered by month)

- Internal Trainings are in French, and the Global Products Specials and Training team are great
cons:
- Distribution of the book of business in a random way. This is unfair, and it is then impossible to reach your targets.

- Favouritism, 

- Unlimited PTO is lies (depending on the manager you have), 

- Not valuing their cs department enough (seen all the colleagues leave the team)

- The HR department does not know the internal processes in the French market, which can be detrimental and impactful. They do not respect the confidentiality of their employees.

- Withholding information on strategies for changing teams, targets or processes, which means that we have to systematically readjust at the last minute, and customers suffer.

- Too many unnecessary meetings.

- Permanent pressure and micro-management in the French market.

headline: Helps people get jobs but doesn't help their employees with their jobs
pros: In a few locations it offers better (slightly) than average compensation and work-life balance.
cons:
Company lacks foresight. For a company that claims to be a data-driven company, it actually fails to avoid problems encountered by other tech companies even if the data is available on how to avoid it. 

It entered a hyper-growth stage with clearly no goals to back it up, which basically hired too many people without a lot of things to do to the point that it actually slowed down hiring during 2019 because it realized it's mistake but don't want to tell everyone about it.

Senior leadership aren't really honest about things, when asked legitimate concerns, it is redirected back to the person asking the concern as another question. This is attributed to the fact that the company hired too many people and basically didn't really completely check if the person they hired was a good fit for the company. Which led to new people basically changing the company's identity and culture and led to attrition to long time employees.

The company now has a culture of re-inventing the wheel and tries to emulate good tech companies but actually just emulates the bad things those tech companies does.

Indeed itself is oblivious to the norms of non-US locations. A lot of perks are given off to US offices but those same perks are never in non-US locations, so much for advertising in a company that thrives in equality.

In terms of equality too, some employees are not well compensated especially those who came from third-world countries. If you are not in a particular role, you don't really have a lot of value within the company which is evident in the compensation difference. A lot of ex-employees who moved to other companies with the same role experienced more compensation equality compared to Indeed.

Unlimited PTO is a lie, basically, you get it as long as you manager approves it. The worst thing about is it that, if you file for PTO, you really won't know if your manager has approved it as part of your unlimited PTO or your regular vacation leave.

Which brings me to the last point, Indeed has hired a lot of people on the leadership roles that aren't really what you call "leaders". These so-called leader never gives value to the people that they "lead" and are always thinking of themselves. These so-called leaders do not know how to effectively manage or lead people. The problem is too that, if Indeed does get people who know how to actually lead, they never try to retain them or support them properly. These so-called leaders have also abused some of the powers by indirectly harassing employees to make themselves voluntarily quit in order for Indeed to not pay for anything. These so-called leaders, never are very selfish and don't understand that they succeed when their people succeed, instead they make themselves succeed and force their subordinates to do things that are not even beneficial for them.

headline: There are greener pastures
pros: There are admittedly solid benefits in the form of decent pay, flexible time off, and good insurance coverage. Other than that I'm not so sure.
cons:
I imagine the rhetoric here will be more skeptical than that in most other reviews of Indeed. But it will serve well those who don't want to drown in koolaid where the only path to a promotion is obsequious habits toward management.

I'll start with the CEO. Chris Hyams is a frustrating leader. Indeed prides itself on diversity and inclusion. Weirdly, though, Hyams injects his political beliefs in an attempt to grovel to the small percentage of employees who demand an answer for every little thing that might enrage them. Our mission is to help people get jobs, not meddle in politics. But the CEO feels the need to be politically correct and gain some easy points through predictable virtue signaling. His answers in our company wide q&as are typically cursory, lacking the detail employees need to plan for the future. He's changed his rhetoric on being so inclusive for people who aren't vaccinated which will most likely lead to folks losing their job when many of the roles can sufficiently be done remotely. 

As far as the day to day goes...two main complaints. The first is simple...the work isn't intellectually stimulating. It's boring, repetitive, and your clients are provincial. The second is the technical issues. Indeed continues to remind its employees that change and adaptability is necessary to survive there. It's an excuse for our technical shortcomings that we have to endure and needlessly troubleshoot, often multiple times a day. 

The last is management and an obscured path to career development. Don't want to be loud and play politics? Good luck. Not to mention, they have some of the dumbest people in management roles that have no business being there. It comes down to not being able to evaluate prospective managers.

headline: Good Company - It's what you make of it
pros:
- Lots of smart people trying to help people get jobs
- Decent benefits
- Decent pay 
- Lots of ambiguity. If you are proactive, you can help shape things and remove some of the ambiguity.
- Lots of opportunities for different work. It really is what you make of it.
cons:
- Work is delivered via quarterly OKRs that are not well-defined. This means there might be lots of pivots and changes throughout the quarter. 
- There are duplicative efforts of the same work happening since work efforts are often silo'd. When you try to bring different silos together, it can be challenging.
- Lots of opinions in project work. While it is great to collaborate with others, it can be challenging when every opinion gets to chime in. At some point, decisions need to be made.
- Lots of ambiguity. This is a pro but can also be a con. Not everyone is capable of being proactive and removing ambiguity. 
- A person's level (i.e. Level 1, Level 2, Level 3, Level 4, Level 5) is very important. This is the only time in my professional career that someone has referenced an internal job level multiple times. Maybe not a con for others, but I find this odd that someone would reference levels.

headline: You don't need Indeed.com to find one of the best employers in Singapore!
pros:
I felt valued from day 1. I was treated with respect by very senior leaders within the company and that my opinions mattered. There were ample opportunities for growth and plenty of support to do what's important.

The culture at Indeed is just wonderful. People were always helpful and not only is it encouraged - it is recognized and rewarded. Indeed does not practice "stack ranking" during performance evaluations which promotes a high level of collaboration between individuals. Evaluations and promotions are highly transparent, which meant that every individual knew what it takes for their own career progression.

The engineering teams in Singapore contribute to efforts that are crucial to Indeed's global machinery. What one does impacts all of Indeed worldwide - the teams here contribute to efforts across very different domains, ranging from payments and apply to our salary and educations product that are used by more than 250m active jobseekers worldwide. There are no lack of interesting, impactful problems to solve!

Compensation for engineering in Indeed is one of the best in the Singapore tech landscape. This is supplemented by excellent healthcare and other "standard" tech benefits like daily catered meals, well stocked pantry and flexible working hours. To prevent people from burning out, Indeed instituted monthly "You days" which are Indeed wide holidays for all employees. On top of that, all employees have unlimited paid-time-off and managers would actively encourage their teammates to utilize this benefit. It is very clear that leadership all the way from the top cares about a healthy work-life balance here in Indeed.

Indeed also embraces working remotely. While the offices have reopened, all employees have the flexibility to work from home or from the office. Indeed provides a small monthly stipend as a WFH allowance.

You won't regret joining Indeed!
cons: The lack of brand prestige working for Indeed is about the only minus I can think of. Indeed is relatively unknown here and that limits Indeed's ability to hire well in this market.

Lack of opportunity to progress over the past 3 years.
Promotions no longer based on merit in most cases.
Lot of needless tasks given to you that take you away from selling.

headline: Best Company I Have Ever Worked For
pros: Great pay, core value of empathy for employees, open PTO plus the whole company is off one day per month. They call these "You Days". Most positions can be 100% remote and all positions can be partially remote. Indeed is such an amazing platform that it sells itself. It is the best in class. Management is wonderful and understanding. All of these things make the very real cons of Indeed worth putting up with.
cons:
Indeed has grown so fast some of their back end systems are built for a smaller company vs. multi billion dollar enterprise. Billing systems are not built for enterprise clients and it causes a lot of problems. 

Sales quotas are blatantly unfair. I do not think this is done on purpose, but your team will have people asked to grow 15% each quarter, and others that will forecast growth but still average a negative quota across the whole year (for no reason like losing clients). It is difficult to watch your peers with consistently super low quotas make a ton more money than you on commission. Even if you grow your revenue more, they will make more money and be more likely to be promoted because Indeed values quota attainment percentages over revenue growth.

headline: Lots of growth potential - great benefits!
pros: I have been employed by Indeed for almost 2 years (started as a contractor). I have enjoyed the journey so far and feel like Indeed truly withholds its values and mission with both jobseekers as well as their employees. I am so happy to have found this organization and am excited to continue to grow, develop, and help people get jobs!
cons: I don't necessarily think that Indeed needs to have contract roles. Being that they are a continuously growing and expanding company, all employees should be brought on permanently right from Day 1 in order to make it feel like a level playing field amongst your peers. From my personal experience, many contractors outperform full time/permanent employee and that alone can create a harsh work culture.

headline: College Frat
pros: Working at Indeed is great if you're looking for a name to boost up your resume but not much else can be said as a pro
cons: Indeed is reminiscent of a college Frat. A lot of smoke and mirror promises as well as many things placed as distractions from the mediocre(at that) work culture. Unlimited PTO and office happy hours are dangled in your face but never accessible if you are underperforming. Resources for help and managers will push you to the wayside if you are in need of help and coaching as they would rather focus on getting more sales for their over performing team members to boost their manager bonus at the end of quarter. When requesting PTO you are often met with "are you sure you should be taking time off when its xyz" usually some sort of guilt statement in order to try and make you rescind your time off. Same goes for employee resource groups or on the clock employee resource meetings and conferences- managers will often ask "how is it you have time for this but not time for more sales?" Unless you are a "cool kid" and drink the "kool-aide" don't expect a very positive/nurturing work environment

headline: Great place to work, been a great few years
pros:
They are constantly innovating and exploring better ways to help the Jobseeker, employers, and our people working here. Inclusivity is discussed every day and acted on. Doing what's best for the job seeker is always the #1 focus. It's fun being on the front lines of change. Yes, it can be messy! 

Senior leadership is always transparent, and there is an open-door policy, which is why I am surprised at some of the reviews here. There are some great opportunities to advance at any level if you work hard enough and do things that will get you noticed.

The people we work with are the biggest Pro. Best team of people in my long career that cares and want to work.
cons:
We need to grow our teams here in Arizona as we are smaller and have had people move into different roles within the company without backfilling.

Fix internal systems as it is hindering the performance of reps. It's a big issue that I know is being addressed, but some considerations would be nice.

headline: Positive
pros: Rewarded for exceeding your goals
cons: Your career Progression is slow

headline: Overall great, if a bit inconsistent
pros:
* Many talented, intelligent people working to solve complex problems, usually at the benefit of the job seeker
* Pretty good in-office perks (snacks, food, game space, ping-pong, lounge, etc. -- though this also varies widely depending on office)
* Unbelievably flexible with PTO (barring Sales and CS, I think) which affords so much leeway in work/life balance
* I have faith leadership (SLT) actually cares about what is going on in the world and with its employees (frequent SLT updates, Q&As, email updates and policy alerts, etc.)
* Overall a pretty casual environment, and one I never feel uncomfortable in even when providing feedback
* Offers ample opportunities to move your career path how you see fit. There are no real barriers to changing roles internally, assuming you pass the interview(s), of course. Though, the process can be a bit sub-par, IMO.
cons:
* Your experience will vary greatly depending on which business unit you are a part of, which office you're in, what your team structure is (fully remote / hybrid / flex / in office, etc.), who your managers are, among other things
* Relatively old tech stack (slowly improving), with ample tech debt that rarely, if ever, gets a chance to be cleaned up/improved
* Absurdly siloed business units, leading to significant problems in communication and coordination, often leading to duplicate or erroneous work being done haphazardly by people with less context of the systems at play
* Salary tends to be on the lower end, especially without inclusion of the bonuses and RSUs
* We sometimes end up having the exact same discussions about particular features or problems because previous discussions were either not actioned, or not shared anywhere so the people with the knowledge are either gone, or are not involved in the new discussions. I am so sick of these redundant meetings.
* Management is completely lost -- I think a large part of this is due to more recent churn in managerial roles, but, overall, in my time here it seems management have a hard time making and sticking with decisions, which leads to chaos as teams scramble to reevaluate their priorities, for example. A recent survey showed that among the largest issues employees were dealing with is their stress level at work, which I wholly attribute to this disorganization with management and their lack of communication and solid direction. SLT I think does fine being 'hands-off' to let the business units make their decisions, but beyond that, top-down it seems like everyone is almost entirely lost, and that feeds into the IC roles. 
* It bugs me when we design things that force users into a particular flow to gather more data on them. The intent is to get more data for internal usage so we make better decisions, but the outcome is forcing people into fewer and fewer workflows, which I imagine many people don't enjoy. (Similar to Glassdoor's move to require you to login to view anything beyond a single page. This just adds frustration to what should be (and used to be) a very simple process!)

headline: Chaos
pros: They have a "You Day" where the whole company takes one day off per month. Salary and benefits were generous.
cons: This was a new team so hardly any of the training materials had anything to do with this role. We were thrown into customer facing situations that we had not been trained for. The scope of the role was constantly changing and morphed into a sales hybrid with hardly any actual implementation work. No guidance from management. As individual contributors, we were asked to create our own role and create our own processes. Communication is so silo'd in the company that it was impossible to function with the start up mentality they wanted us to have. You can't talk to another team, you have to open a JIRA ticket and wait for someone to be assigned to it. Internal resources and tools were scarce. We were regularly asked to do things that the directors or senior directors should have been handling. It's non unusual for Indeed products to turnover - they just shuffle employees around from product to product. Morale is incredibly low as a result. Managers were more concerned with picking cute team names and mascots than doing anything that would help the team understand what the job entails. Leadership would announce in large department meetings that our team was going to do things that clearly weren't in our job description. Toxic positivity abounds.

headline: Not Great
pros:
-Company treated staff great at the start of the pandemic. Good experience when you have a great manager

-Quarterly bonus

-Great new office in Dublin! Though a bit hard to reach
cons:
Cons

- The biggest con; the nepotism in the different departments, especially Sales and Client Success. If you have a great manager, you have a good experience if you 'click' with them. If you have a less than great manager, you'll have a less than good experience, to downright awful.

- Indeed uses two parallel systems to track anything from Finance, Sales, Support etc. This means that there is a lot of extra work to be done that isn't efficient and distracts from your job. The Tech Stack is cobbled together, not crafted from a singular perspective.

-KPIs are constantly changing, and the work itself is transforming into simple Call-center work.

-There had been a hiring freeze and this caused very limited chances to grow in the company. 

-Unlimited PTO isn't unlimited anymore. In Sale and CS it doesn't count for much unless you overreach your target significantly AND you're in good standing with your manager. Even then, it's only slightly more.

-Indeed is data-driven, but is it in a very superficial way. They don't look deeper into the numbers, and don't derive any real value from their numbers. i.e. Markets reaching their targets is a simple yes or no. No deeper analysis into how and why. 
Another example, Indeed wants to grow and get 'closer to the hire' because they've noticed the recruiting industry is much larger than what they have been aiming for. They didn't analyse their value to their clients, but simply decided to throw a product in to 'get closer to the hire' that hardly works.

-The pay and benefits at other Tech companies in Dublin are way better.

-This would, partially, explain why Indeed has a hard time attracting or keeping skilled personnel. There had been a hiring freeze for a year and a half, and the departments kept shrinking, while the work kept piling up. This is in particular for the UK and especially BeNeLux team

-The product itself isn't really great. A lot of extra tools they roll-out aren't fully developed. They could definitely take more time in thinking this through.

headline: Tells a nice story, but over all doesn't see the people behind the numbers
pros:
- Large focus on training and developing skills
- Unlimited PTO - at your manager's discretion.
- The first step in career progression is very attainable and "mechanical". Do the action, get the promotion. Every step after that is a different story.
cons:
- LOT'S of box-ticking excercises. Indeed use two parallel business systems, and integration between these two systems often means none of them work as intended. This makes the required boxticking exercises much harder, as the boxes ticked don't always show to be ticked to all stakeholders. Same with overarching analysis software.

- Very data driven decision-making, yet there is no interest in looking into numbers at more than face value. Is your market hitting your targets? Yes or no - that's all of it. 

- Struggling to attract and keep skilled personnel, meaning all departments are constantly short-staffed. 

- Very dependant on your director. Good experiences with a good manager, but very bad experiences with a mediocre manager. Terrible experiences with a bad manager. During my 2 years at Indeed, I had 6 different directors. Each time we'd go over the same problems and land in the same "unacceptable" work-arounds (this process would take around 6-8 weeks each time).

- Lot's of unskilled managers, and teams tend to look for "culture fit", not "culture add". In practice, this means that if you don't naturally do things the same way as your manager, regardless of your results, you will be considered problematic.

headline: Challenging yet wonderful experience in my career
pros:
From day 1, I felt very welcomed and included at Indeed. Their culture of transparency and providing consistent support to their employees wellbeing has undoubtedly set me up for success in my career and to develop my personal growth.

While there is a lot of learning about the product and how to explain it in layman terms, Indeed provided a lot of training opportunities and coaching from experienced managers to help you achieve your goals.

If you work in Sales, it will be a challenging experience and it's important to be on top of your book of business. However, if you disqualify, manage your time and focus on the clients that want to talk to you and need your help, then you will reach your quota and open a lot of doors for your personal brand as well as expand your network.

I learned so much from Indeed, my managers, and peers that hone in on my soft skills so no doubt that it made me more resilient and adaptive to the current environment and more importantly work effectively as a team to reach our goals.

Other nice perks include unlimited PTO, work-home balance, work from home allowance and free swag.
cons:
Communication with other teams located in different offices across the globe can lead to delays in getting campaigns started and issues resolved which can be frustrating. 

Sometimes they ask you to create a ticket again after raising the incorrect one or if there is information missing, you need to start from the beginning in raising a case again. This sort of admin work is unnecessary and adds to an already heavy workload to AEs so if there is a little flexibility introduced to this then it would really drive results faster.

When you sell an annual subscription, you can only receive a quarter of the revenue added to your dash each quarter. If the account moves to Growth then the new rep gets the remaining revenue due despite the fact that you closed an annual deal.

cons:
-The CEO and other lead execs of the company are extremely Liberal politically and constantly pushes those beliefs on the entire company in weekly emails, Q&A's, policies, etc. If you are disturbed by political beliefs being pushed on you or constantly in your face you may be regularly frustrated here
-Working from home is tough due to difficulty learning, it's taking much longer to become an expert in my role due to this. Hoping to return to the office setting in Jan 2022 currently

headline: Good teammates, bad career growth, terrible salary
pros: Classic tech benefits. CS teams seemed to be cohesive and get a long so that shows good culture emphasized from direct managers there.
cons:
Senior leadership is so far removed from the definition of a healthy salary and they make many excuses as to why they do not give healthy raises and make excuses as to why they do not want to open senior positions to promote individuals. The organizational relationship and set up between CS and Sales makes it easy for Sales to take advantage of CS and take the credit for the hard work that CS does for their Sales partners. Of course, CS also isn't "set up" to earn commission on the sales they help their Sales counterparts to make which is just wrong. After so many years of helping Indeed grow it's disappointing that they do not promote within from CS seasoned employees but hire less experienced job seekers at a cheaper price.

Truly this job would be excellent for college graduates to get their experience and leave however, the job description requires more than 1 years of experience.

headline: High-Pressure, High Quotas
pros: Good benefits, friendly co-workers, decent base pay, amazing amenities.

Quotas ramp up extremely fast. Your book of business will dry out in a few days and all that's left to pick are people who have been called nonstop so it's impossible to start a conversation. 

The ends justify the means. If you can meet your quota it doesn't matter if someone was left unsatisfied or confused by your high-pressure sales pitch.

headline: Perfect career for recruiter

headline: Lack of Growth Opportunities
pros:
1. Great offices! Not as relevant during the pandemic but definitely worth mentioning.

2. I've met some great people at Indeed. Made plenty of friendships that I believe will last a long time.

3. The company mission is admirable. It was relatively easy to connect the dots as to how my job positively impacted others. 

4. Indeed has great brand recognition and the product practically sells itself.

5. Indeed did not have layoffs during the pandemic, and I am grateful for this.
cons:
1. Indeed Client Success is grossly underpaid. If you want to be paid what you're worth, Indeed Client Success is not the place to do it.

2. It's difficult to get promoted unless you're in the right place at the right time, and know the right people. Your career and pay growth is largely out of your control.

3. The best perks of working at Indeed are all tied to being in the office. Once the office perks were taken away, it was easier to see where Indeed was lacking, and many are quitting as the job market recovers and receiving significant pay increases elsewhere.

4. Semi-annual reviews in Client Success are extremely subjective. I would be scored in categories like Collaborate, Initiate, and Execute by a leader that didn't even understand the magnitude of the work that I was doing and was horrible at showing appreciation. There seems to be some unspoken rule amongst CS leaders that no matter what someone in CS does, they can never get a "perfect score" on their review. This is a practice that discourages employees from trying to go above and beyond.

5. It seems like every 2 years Indeed makes a drastic shift that completely changes the role of CS and Sales. Recently, there was a re-org where teams were broken up with little notice. From a CS rep's perspective, this means that you were most likely placed on a different team, with a different manager, with different sales partners, with different accounts, and no pay adjustment.

6. Indeed CS has a practice of putting people in "Interim" Manager or Team Lead roles and not paying people for the work that they are doing. For example, a Team Lead may work as an Interim Manager for several months without being paid like a Manager. In my opinion, this practice needs to stop.

7. For some reason Indeed has made it extremely difficult to transition from Inside Sales CS to Enterprise CS even though it's essentially the same job. For people that don't want to follow a leadership path, transitioning into Enterprise CS is pretty much the only way to see meaningful career growth within CS. So if you can't transition to Enterprise and you aren't interested in being a CS leader at Indeed, it's in your best interest to move on to a new company.

8. Indeed leadership has a way of guilt tripping you into thinking that there's no other company like Indeed, the grass isn't greener elsewhere, etc. That's completely false. There are so many awesome tech companies in New York, Austin, and the Bay Area that have the same or even better perks than Indeed and pay significantly better.

9. I appreciate that Indeed as a whole seems to value inclusivity and diversity, however, I wish that a senior leader would have taken the time to reach out and talk to me 1:1 about diversity and inclusion related topics, even if just for 15 minutes. That would have meant so much more to me than hearing about it at another All-Hands meeting or any other group setting. Personally, I don't want to hear a white man or woman telling me what needs to be done to improve diversity without them having listened to my input first.

- It's sluggish
- You have to deal with many stakeholders whose only goal is to minimize their workload and strongly resist to change the way they work. I think this is pretty standard in any company, but if you come from a startup, you might find this very disheartening (it was for me).

headline: Amazing place to work

headline: Great company, does not know what clients truly want
pros: Great training, very kind inclusive culture, pay is good but base pay puts you in a smaller tax bracket meaning HIGH taxes to your bonus (most of your pay)
cons: Does not see the "want" from clients and tries too hard to implement change where it is NOT needed. Constantly tries to "improve" technology while simultaneously removing key functions that clients like to use, leading to churn. New technologies are simply not good enough and scalable for clients to truly buy in. There is a massive disconnect between OKR's and what clients are truly striving for with their commitment to us.

And not only during the pandemic, everyone at Indeed has a clear idea of where the company is going and what our goals are.

headline: Things started off well at least
pros: Unlimited PTO if you can take it. Excellent health insurance. Pay is fine, not amazing but competitive. I am lucky to work on a truly talented team with good people.
cons:
This company grew too quickly and is now truly rudderless. Those who joined Indeed early are out of their depth but have been promoted into leadership and don't have the skills or acumen to lead. There is no strategy other than to launch beta products and bet the bank on them. 

Marketing especially is a total mess. There are small pockets of talented people here and there but lots of people who just coast along for a paycheck because no one ever gets let go. No top level marketing goals, zero colloboration, teams compete all the time and overlap. There is not a path for career growth and the whole org gets dinged for ineptitude. Teams are imploding. Focus on short term vs long term conversions. No long term strategy. 

Add to the mix toxic and clueless managers who bully their teams (with no recourse), teams that fight over OKRs, no clear scope, lack of marketing tech to track outcomes and rampant favoritism. Planning to get the heck outta here.

headline: Going Downhill & Low Pay for a "Tech" Company
pros: Flexible Schedule, Remote, work from home, good health/vision/dental, and mostly everyone is welcoming!
cons: Workloads are often mismatched and sold to you as temporary until they can hire someone else. This happens A LOT. You will always be covering for someone. SLT seems to have a clear vision but it's not being executed well. They are forcing products to roll out quickly that are half-baked and then act shocked when our Enterprise clients are angry the products do not work or break etc. CS and Sales are on the front lines of these conversations as all other teams at Indeed refuse to be client facing. You will never get a market standard salary. Indeed is low paying in comparison to the industry and you can expect very small raises and HUGE pay bands. Externals will be brought in at the top of a pay band doing half the work of people that started just a few years ago. So it's causing a lot of turnover.

headline: Sub-standard quality of work, below avg team, but with great pay
pros:
- People are generally friendly and good to talk to
- Pay is top of the market for Singapore. Since they have limited brand value in the market, they pay big bucks to compensate to buy out people from other companies.
cons:
- Lots of talk, but little real action: Since Indeed in Singapore hires a lot more “managers who talk fancy” rather than “actual doers”, there’s very little work that actually gets accomplished on a weekly basis. Most work gets caught up in holding patterns of useless debates/micro-alignment, and eventually teams celebrate tiny A/B tests at the end of 3 months as “massive impact”. The actual amount of work that gets each quarter is a joke, really!

- The office is pretty much a satellite engineering office for the most part: Strategy/goals gets “handed down from the top” from US bosses. Or even if the teams come up with bottom-up ideas — they need “permission from the top” to even try it out. The culture is very top-down for the most part.

- The management in the US doesn’t trust the teams in Singapore, hence prepare to be micro-managed a lot. Have a problem with micro-management? Sorry, you’re not “aligned” — don’t even try pushing back as micro-management (ex: getting your simple A/B experiments approved before testing) is the expected cultural norm here.

- Culture in Singapore reminds you a lot of working in a large bank: Lots of politics, people sweet-talking on the face while they complain behind your back, lots of talk around process yet very little work actually gets done, leaders who do a lot of theoretical pseudo-intellectual debates but with little practical implementation knowledge nor experience.

- Hiring processes are broken: The quality of the people varies a lot. You might find an occasional outlier rockstar but huge variations in quality of folks. From a Singapore standpoint, the overall avg engineering quality is definitely below market, and part of it can also be attributed to the quality of product-mandates held by Singapore teams — since the work is not very challenging, you don’t tend to attract the best engineers anyways! How many engineers would just want to move around a couple of buttons everyday?

headline: Great mission, Great people, Expansive opportunity to make an impact
pros: Amazing overall culture. Some jobs are more fulfilling than others and working for a company with such a wonderful, empowering mission of getting people jobs is great experience. People are supportive. There are career flex opportunities (if you show the initiative). The salary/benefits are fantastic.
cons: A lot of consistent change. You have to be OK with being uncomfortable at times. But that's where a great team like Indeed can make change "exciting" instead of "scary".

headline: Lots its vision
pros: For the most past Indeed was a great place to work for many years. The people were great, the pay was decent and leadership was very understanding through all of covid. The health benefits were amazing and you could really take a lot of the unlimited PTO is you were doing your work the rest of the time.
cons:
The biggest con is that leadership and the company seem to be adrift. A lot of senior members of the leadership team have left in the last 9 months and the company has seemed to have lost its way. They are constantly putting new product tweaks in place that are hurting employers and aren't wanted by them. The engineering teams seem to think they know what the clients wants but sales and CS, on the front lines, are having to deal with angry employers and having to explain why they are getting a worse ROI month after month. The company also keeps investing in side projects that don't work and are spending too long on them and too much money.

There is also a lot of lip service about DE&I but other than IRGs there isn't a lot of changes happening in management.

headline: Not inclusive of neurodiversity
pros: Money, money, money. Second highest salary for tech work in Tokyo next to Google. WFH stipends.
cons:
Politics.
The company released a laughable neurodiversity training. NOT inclusive of neurodiversity. Indeed treats it like a disability instead.
Posturing is far too important in this very vertical company structure.
Expect retaliation for constructive feedback and escalating toxic behavior. Did your engineers come to work at 3pm and miss standup for a month? Well, the eng manager will retaliate if you escalate to their manager. Did your designer just yell at the engineers? Well, don't escalate that to their manager or you'll get retaliated against for that too. 
Indeed hires children who care more about office perks and happy hours than showing up and doing their jobs.
Did you just deliver insane results? Well, keep that up for three review cycles and you'll get a 7% raise.
The HR and accounting in Japan is a joke. Accounting will ruin your taxes guaranteed. HR is less useful than talking to a template email. It's Recruit's backoffice so what can you expect from a typical Japanese company?

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Great people, great leadership team, great perks. Through COVID, the response from the business (senior leaders particularly) was absolutely amazing, with laying off staff being the last thing they even thought of. Stipends to set up home offices, extra days off ("YOU Days") to help rest and relax, the list goes on.
On top of this, the extra benefits (e.g. Healthcare, Unlimited PTO, extra Super) all add up to make it a really competitive remuneration package and one that's incredibly fair
Definitely recommend working here
cons:
Targets, as with all sales roles, are hard to predict. There's both 'easy' and 'very hard' targets, and this can make the role frustrating.
Being a 'challenger' in AU also makes it a somewhat 'tougher' sell

headline: Great company to be in, especially now, during these tough times.
pros:
1) Inclusive
2) Great level of transparency, 
3) Great benefits
4) We have the best Head of HR ever (Generally speaking, all members of the Senior Leadership Team are impressively good at their job)
5) Following Covid times, Flexibility is the one aspect the company is really investing into
6) amazing work/life balance
cons:
If you ask them, most employees will tell you Indeed doesn't pay as much as other big tech companies in the business.
What I think is that if you make money your priority, yes, there will be companies that will definitely pay more. 
However, if you value flexibility and work-life balance (not integration, as they call it in some other BIG tech companies) more than just money, Indeed is the place to be.

headline: Decent company, not a lot of room to move up
pros: Indeed is very inclusive and had a fantastic pandemic response. They also have a great work/life balance. The work style here is very independent and there is no micromanaging. You really have the opportunity to be self-sufficient. While we were not WFH, the in-office perks were phenomenal.
cons: Upward mobility is VERY competitive. There is an extensive interview process for every promotion, and it's very common not to get promoted on the first or even second try. Client Success is also extremely underpaid.

headline: No place is perfect, but they REALLY take care of employees
pros: Only HR Tech company that didnt do layoffs during COVID. Regularly supportive of taking time off and taking care of family and other stuff as needed.

headline: Grew Too Fast
pros: Unlimited PTO, free meals, cool office aesthetics, smart colleagues, some friendly people to work with.
cons:
When I first started, Indeed had more of a laid back "startup" feel. That started to fade away when it grew tremendously in 2016, 2017, 2018, etc. Indeed has a "no jerks" policy, but that didn't seem to be applied as much as the years went on. Top talent people from the West and East Coast were brought in for brainpower, but with that often came huge egos and underdeveloped emotional intelligence/social skills. Entitled "geniuses" started roaming around the office.

Pay was also quite low for my department. Some departments might of been different, but they claimed all of the cushy techy perks were justification for below average pay. This was in Austin when the housing/rent prices began skyrocketing as an influx of transplants kept rolling in. 

Management was pretty incompetent in my department. Lots of favoritism and college cliquey vibes that got unqualified people promoted if they were within that clique.

There was a lot of pressure to hang out at the office as much as possible. It was a good gig for recent grads, but a lot of people had their entire lives and identifies embedded in the Indeedian work culture. If you didn't want to partake in all of that, it was a bit to your disadvantage.



Depending o

headline: Fantastic company to work in!

All communication from the top down has been very clear and transparent. Live Q&As with C-level managers gives you so much confidence in the business and its direction. 

We've been able to expensive anything you want to make a comfortable office at home too. 

Senior managers and managers are more than willing to help and guide you on your career path here. Even over this difficult time they could not be more supportive. Thank you.

headline: Great Job - My time to go
pros: I loved working at indeed right out of college for about 3 years. The culture is perfect for a transition out of college as well as great compensation as a sales rep for hitting your quarterly quotas. The training is unmatched with Dale Carnegie training as you progress in your career at indeed. The work life balance is great especially in the sales team as there are strict hours that you can be online. However, if you are looking to get ahead by putting in extra time this is not possible.
cons:
You can progress quickly to Senior Account Exective however, after this there are fewer opportunities to grow in your career for someone who was looking for a more complex sales cycle it was time for me to move on.

Management is young so is great at selling indeeds product but does not have a lot of experience outside of that. I found that it was difficult for them to assist outside of their selling style.

headline: There's more to life than free snacks

headline: Great organization with a mission and focus on career growth
pros:
- Indeed serves a basic human and economic need for all kinds of people
- Best tech employer in Austin, good opportunities to stay long-term or grow career
- Engineering has high hiring standards without dogmatic rules or fanatic expectations
- Clear leader in job search but still innovating and looking for new opportunities
- Transparent and competitive salaries and finally switching to equity compensation
- Culture puts emphasis on sustainable work-life balance over heroism
- No employee layoffs at all when COVID hit, which shows good character
- Opportunity for nearly all roles to work remotely without need for manager approval
cons:
- Business-driven, pragmatic focus to innovation means few research opportunities for academic backgrounds
- Although talent is reliably in top 5%, talent in top 1% is much more rare than at big-N tech companies for some reason (location? recruiting?).
- Amazing office spaces, in-office catering, amenities and events now mean nothing
- Still unclear what new normal will be like after COVID

headline: I WISH I COULD RECOMMEND Indeed , BUT I CANT

cons: Career progression and rewards and recognition would need to improve. Zero budget put in for training, upskilling. People leave and do not get replaced. Senior management leaving bad sign of a sinking ship. New technology could be improved. Salaries also could be improved. Most of the management I was exposed to had been field promoted. Because someone had some technical skill does not make them a good manager. Time served and who you spent time with in work seemed to matter most. If you worked hard and did well in your job, you would never leave it.

headline: Outstanding adventure with this amazing company
pros:
Top of the range financial package with fantastic flexibility, allowing for a great work life balance. 
Coming up to 4 years at the company and I have enjoyed every moment. Leadership is brilliant, we have a very inclusive environment locally in my office, and globally in our approach to diversity, inclusion and belonging. We still should continue to keep pushing in the right direction and not get complacent.
Overall the impact Indeed has made on my life is substantial and I do really feel that our ethos to 'help people get jobs' drive the company forward, allows us to be flexible with our technology, while trying to compete at a top level within the competitive recruitment landscape.
cons: Internal bureaucracy can be frustrating, however this is clutching at straws. Working at indeed has been a pleasure 99.9% of the time.

headline: Product
pros: Best culture of any Tech company I've ever worked at
cons: 'Lean Startup' based product development philosophy (A|B test - driven development) works well in many ways but often results in products losing cohesion in terms of design and vision. Emphasis on short-term impact in performance evaluations creates a strong disincentive to prioritize important work that takes more than a quarter to show value.

headline: Love, love, love Indeed
pros: Indeed offers amazing benefits, which easily keep me engaged and excited about work. Open PTO, tons of e-learnings, very close-knit groups of employees.
cons: The vision is clear, but the path toward achieving the vision changes often. For an established company, it's sometimes frustrating to have different KPIs, goals, expectations, etc. each quarter. Transparency is key, and while management is regularly communicating with employees, the communication is sometimes vague.

headline: Look out!
pros: nice in-office perks with tons of free food, well appointed offices, frequent office events, strong purpose and brand, generally open communications from senior management
cons:
Oof....where to start. The recruiting blitz is strong and they strive for a 6 star experience if you make it to an interview. Salaries are toward the lower end from what I heard and what I learned as a hiring manager although manages are not allowed to know what their employees earn. They strive to make up for lower salaries in perks. (Not sure how that is going in these wfh days.) For a while, they were hiring like gangbusters with new employees getting a fresh Macbook Air. So you have a lot of young people without much structure running around looking busy but without much direction or results. The demographics and age range definitely slants younger and there is a lot 'coaching' asked of managers. There is also an emphasis in performance management with repeated feedback both up and down. However, this gives a disproportionate amount of leverage to lower level staff who in many ways have become entitled and coddled. And too many avenues for people to push back on their managers covertly. This creates a very superficial environment with happiness on the outside but a lot of back stabbing behind the scenes. It's unfortunate as the mission and progressiveness of the company are in the right place. The Indeed brand and marketplace standing are strong and the Japanese holding company who owns Indeed is throwing money at it like it's going out of style. (This must be a classic pump and dump strategy to sell this firm.)
I would avoid jobs in program management as they are frequently glorified admins. The Product side is generally strong.
Like any job, proceed at your own risk. In full disclosure, I'm an experienced middle manager with a strong CV who was there 15 months and couldn't get out fast enough.

headline: Choose the team you apply to very carefully
pros: Good perks, some great teams (direct sales teams, marketing, hr and IT) nice office
cons: Middle management (outside of direct sales), particularly those linked to sales daily function are very poor. A lot come from well known corporate tech companies and have a school teacher approach. Promotions are rare, demotions are common. Up to roughly 2 years ago company was booming, but big changes in Senior Management and hiring of extremely young inside sales reps, changed the dynamic completely. Massively relient on minimum wage type jobs for site, mid to Senior jobs do not perform well on site, at all. Warehouse workers, HC assistants etc are reason for volume of monthly visit numbers. Missed big chances to develop into a game changing company, other companies, new software and Covid will have really significant repercussions for the business

headline: Indeed is like an abusive partner
pros: Nothing; all this place has to recommend it is branding.
cons:
Indeed's is a culture hostile to inclusion. It's also hostile to the concept of elevating people, and specifically women of color, and most specifically, Black women. As a NBWOC, not only was I constantly denied a promotion despite increasing responsibility, I saw the same done to other NBPOC but specifically to Black women, and to the worst degree. 

Any woman whose personality didn't fit a model of white femininity was bullied, shunned, or essentially demoted. This place destroyed my soul and made me think that every single manager I will ever have will be toxic and abusive. I had dealings with two abusive managers at Indeed, and a slew of ones who didn't care to grow my skills. Ironically, the two 'leaders' who foisted the most work onto my plate without a promotion saw me become one fo the most essential member of both teams, at which time they decided it was time to take most of my responsibilities away. This was presumably because I made them feel threatened in some way, judging by how their white friends were promoted over me. Of course, both of these managers were white.

In the early days of Seen by Indeed, it was called Indeed Prime, and run by people who retaliated against POC who dared to give the leaders of the product a presentation about why targeting diverse candidates and people of color specifically was a solid business strategy that was already being pursued by our main competitor, Hired. It was a no-brainer, but since we gave the presentation to fragile white people, the result was retaliation in the form of verbal or managerial sidelining. Our personalities were proclaimed to be aggressive. The white man I worked for on Indeed Prime actually told me that my co-workers had given him feedback that I was aggressive and needed to tone down my personality - straight out of the racist workplace playbook. This same manager also mocked the accents of offshore contractors in front of me, about which HR did nothing. That manager later moved to a job in the Recruiting department, and is probably still there, because Indeed protects abusive, racist people, and really loves protecting bad managers with multiple HR complaints against them.

That was just the beginning. In both of my roles there, I was given work far beyond the scope of my job description. Forget a raise, I had to FIGHT for a title change to one that described all the work I actually did. Neither time did I actually get a title change, either. I moved to a different department for the next two of my three years at this company, and came across the second abusive manager, a white woman, who proceeded to hire another white woman who was her friend, who then bullied a third white woman on my team. Bullying is intersectional.

By the end of my tenure at Indeed, I had gone to HR about three separate white people who had bullied me in various documented ways, and HR did nothing. They claimed to do an investigation, but no one was fired, or even reprimanded, or prevented from getting a different role at Indeed. I'm always going to carry resentment from my time there because of the abusive behavior that's tolerated. The last straw was the Director of Diversity and Inclusion leaving. Y'all know why that was.

headline: Great perks but disappointing work experience
pros:
Great health benefits and other exclusive perks but many are for PERMANENT employees only

They really try their best for employee wellbeing 
- Friendly workmates
- Casual dress code
- Free food and drinks
- Relaxed, fun work culture
- Regular social events
- Great place for graduates to start their career
- Diverse cultural background employees
cons:
- Limited growth in the Sydney headquarter
- Extremely high turnover rate (Every month at least one person in our team would either quit themselves including a few managers, or could be fired on the spot because they couldn't reach their KPI)
- The product Indeed selling is not appealing enough and they are not willing to orientate it to fit the APAC market well
- Had to handle an enormous amount of client complaints due to the weakness of the product
- Felt like scamming clients because the product you are offering is not good enough because you already knew that they wont get good candidates (mostly overseas applicants) 
- Limited communication from the US updates about the website, leaving us unaware of changes made to the website when we tried to communicate with clients
- What you always hear when you gave feedback to managers is "You know we cant do anything about that" because themselves also realise they have limited power to change anything
- You get promoted based on whether your senior manager like you or not, not by how long you've been worked for. I've seen employees who definitely deserve a promotion with great performance and can give constructive feedback working for 2 -3 years but still in the same position since they started

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: Indeed was an excellent place for me to start out my infosec career. I found that the management on the team was accomodating to my own goals and needs, and I was able to pursue a variety of projects in line with my interests and growth. Also the pay is pretty good, and there's a lot of excellent benefits like unlimited PTO and onsite cafeterias.
cons: As the company grew larger it seemed like it started to become filled with more beauracratic processes and it was harder to stay in touch with everything happening on the team. Overall though I greatly enjoyed the experience.

headline: Great place that could be improved
pros:
- Customer-focused company: if you don't understand why are you doing something, it's either you're doing something completely wrong (and better to raise it up immediately), or you just don't know something (and better to learn in ASAP)
- Almost no communications barriers: you could directly approach anybody, directly go and even edit almost any information source and codebase - and that would be very much welcomed
- Processes in the company are a great help and not the obstacle to almost anything you'll want to do be it some personal stuff or some initiative
- Unlimited PTO was a great thing for me for personal things - I'm guilty to borderline abuse it:)
- Truly international company with huge amount of people from US, China (including new grads), Japan (including new grads), and literally countries all across the globe (Brazil, Israel, Spain, Singapore to name a few)
- Data-based everything from evaluation presentations to product decisions to interviews
cons:
- Tokyo office steadily becomes an execution office with all the interesting/impactful work steadily been moved to US
- I'd suggest to avoid Japanese managers: even if they're great people in person, I'm not aware of a single case when they didn't brought Japanese-style management under guise: shift responsibility, blame your team, micromanage, boss around etc. That doesn't apply to non-Japanese managers who are majority.
- Advise: impact matters above everything else. Management don't communicate it clearly, so expect to adjust first quarter or two. Optimise for maximum impact with minimal effort, push back everything else.

headline: Good company, stuck in old ways

Well known global brand
Free breakfast

Tries to be an everyman so the products get rolled out without proof of concept and sales people are forced to sell something that doesn't work for the customers
Lots of nepotism in order to progress and it's still very bro-focused on the sales floor
HR is terrible, they aren't trained compliantly and don't give credence to real employee concerns
Workload is not distributed properly
There is literally no trust - managers will sweep the floor looking for people not at their desks, and chastise employees for taking breaks or using personal call booths (why are they there then?)
Painfully start-uppy for how established they are

headline: It's in moments like these when sr. management should shine - And they did.
pros:
- Sr. Leadership provides a clear vision, EVERYONE at Indeed knows where we're going and how. 
- Amazing response to a stressful situation like Covid-19, weekly Q&A's and regular email updates. I can't be more grateful to have someone at the helm that knows what they're doing and understands the importance of keeping employees informed.
- Growth opportunities, I had the chance to move internally to a job I liked more.
cons: As in any company, sometimes those growth opportunities may not be there. The role has to exist first.

headline: Not human at all.
pros: Breakfast and new office, this job may be good if you want to start in sales to learn the fundamentals of cold calling but don’t stay more than a year because you could have a burnout.
cons:
You can’t take a break whenever you want.
Your manager will make you understand that the way you are working is more important than your results. 
You have no responsibility, you just cold call 60 to 80 times a day without any go to market strategy. 
You don’t feel unique within this environment at all. 
They call it Account Executive role, it’s just an Inside Sales role with no value in term of sales strategy. 
Talking about pressure, you will be squeeze like a lemon for nothing. 
The mentality of people on the floor wasn’t welcoming, you can feel that people are stressed.

headline: Engaging and rewarding workplace
pros:
Lots of changes in UK Acquisition lately but the business is continuously adapting. 

Management have done an excellent job keeping AEs motivated and engaged by providing trainings and regular updates. 

Days are stimulating and very rewarding. Always feel like I’m learning and improving under the guidance of leadership.
cons: Some periods can be stressful but that’s the nature of the business.

headline: Great employee, huge focus on employee experience and welfare
pros:
Well paid, plenty of opportunities for career progression, training and development.

Realistic targets given to sales org and Acq after pandemic, supportive management from directors and TLs focusing on employee development and positive reinforcement during unprecedented time for the business. 

Great benefits, healthcare, food, events, and many resources available to all employees.

Excellent Senior Leadership, particularly demonstrated during Covid-19 with a policy to ensuring all employees are looked after, and prioritising their health and safety.

Tight knit teams, friendly and welcoming atmosphere. Huge supports available to those who are struggling if requested.
cons:
Heavy focus on Indeed brand can feel a little artificial, but this can be engaged with or not as desired.

This is the only criticism I could think of, I would highly recommend this company to anybody.

There aren't any RSUs like you'd get at public companies so that part of your pay may be less than elsewhere.

headline: Great company - Dreadful Managers in UK/IE
pros:
Indeed it's SLT had an amazing and humbling response to Covid 19.
Lay offs as a last resort.
Guarantee % of bonus, even if under performed as the market is struggling.
Quata adjustment for Q1 as market shifted.
The message has consistently been, help out where you can, plan for recovery, keep safe.
cons: So I have been at Indeed over 2 years now, and have had there has always been an issue with management, however what is particularly frustrating is that in the ACQ org, the message being put out there is seemingly the exact opposite of the SLT, pushing  for hard close, chase your tagrget above everything else, and if you underperform you're a free loader because you're garaunteed your bonus.

headline: Great for Entry Level Sales bad for Career Longevity
pros:
Great entry level job 
you can make a lot of money quickly (170k to 220k I believe is an accurate rage)
easy product to learn and sell
great products that work well for clients 
good training program in place for the first couple of years with the company
cons:
not many long term growth opportunities 
fake unlimited PTO policy for sales (company uses it for marketing purposes) 

career education and growth stops after 2 years of working with the company

Sometimes you can get shafted based on the accounts that they give you. Some reps were easily making 200,000K and had dream clients given to them, while other reps were given very hard to sell, less qualified, clients. 

You can easily be given a bad book of business and be the best sales person, yet make much less than one of your colleagues who is an inferior sales person but had the ideal clients who are spending a ton. 
It killed moral and made you feel that the environment was not merit based.

headline: Indeed takes care of its employees

cons: Not the funnest place to work if you're not hitting targets.

headline: Great Place To Work

cons: Pressure (as in most sales roles) however targets are genuinely achievable

headline: Worst management team, you'll regret to join here
pros: Great employee perks including top class health insurances, free drinks and snacks
cons:
The worst working experience I've ever encountered. 
-No work life balance.
In the interview, I was told there is awesome work life balance here, and almost no OT here which is totally not the truth. You are expected to work 10-12 hours a day. Though it's not enforced directly, it is implied by team lead and manager. They assigned you the overwhelmed work to do which is even out of your job scope, then told you that you can stop your work at 6pm. But the workload is definitely couldn't be finished before 6pm. Even you sacrifice yourself and work overtime every day, the work will never be completed. Because they keep assigning you the work more and more, and lastly give you the worst and false evaluation even though how hard you worked.

-Poor management.
Poorest management team, you couldn’t imagine a team can be leaded by these kinds of people: they are emotional, unprofessional, childish, lack of basic working knowledge. They couldn’t accept any different voice, and keep building “yes-man” around them. The leads keep making mistakes but all will become subordinate’s faults, that’s their way. 

-Office politics.
It’s so funny even there is office politics in such a small team, and 2 team leads in the same team. The power-hungry leads use their subordinates as a tool to fight for their promotion. So, subordinates must become victims.

-Border bullying culture
Harassment behavior from team leaders and managers. Even they have an ethical team or HR department who should take care of this kind of issue, and you reported to them you have mentally exhausted due to endless border bullying, but no one take care of this issue seriously, and no one will care you, anyway you’re replaceable. And the team leader even told you, if you couldn’t endure then quit here.

headline: Good Company to Work for
pros: Work Culture, Open PTO, Innovative solutions, High on Benifits.
cons: Need to look at Simplify some of the processes, management need to be more transparent.

headline: Incredibly well looked after even in these unprecedented times
pros:
Constantly putting employees, clients and general public ahead of gains.

A great way of assessing a companies core values is not how they treat people during the good times, but how they go above and beyond to look after it’s employees during the worst times.
The fact that Indeed were one of the first to make the move to WFH for all employees during the early days of Covid19 speaks volumes. Making an effort to retain all current staff making sure that if a role becomes dormant IE. Talent attraction that can move to another part of the business. Open and honest Q&As with CEO and other SLTs where they are incredibly vulnerable and open and really show that they are also people with family and friends the same as us all. Truly fantastic bunch of people and make working at Indeed a privilege
cons: Honestly besides the actual job itself being tough, there are no cons.

headline: Good place to work

headline: Good perks no transparent goals

headline: A really great and inclusive work culture
pros:
I have been working at Indeed for 3 years now. This is an honest review and I can honestly say that I really love working at Indeed. I work in the UK Growth A department and I have to say that I go to work with a smile on my face every day. The team I am on is amazing and I have really grown in so many ways. There is a really healthy culture of inclusion here, everybody is respected and appreciated. Indeed knows how to look after their staff.

I have been so impressed with how they have handled this difficult time through COVID and the uncertainty that surrounds it all. Culture is first and foremost at this company. Yes you have to work hard but hard work is rewarded, the team spirit in Growth A is second to none.

There are many great inclusion groups at Indeed, from "Women at Indeed" to parents inclusion groups, LGBT and many more. We also have great benefits such as PTO, healthcare, dental care and much more.

Indeed has not only helped my career but it has been so supportive in my personal life, even offering support through difficult times and particularly my director has been so supportive. I can not express my gratitude enough for having been hired at this company. So if you are thinking of starting a career in sales, Indeed is one of the best companies you could choose.
cons: To be honest, I have not found any, sales is always going to a tough job but the rewards are greater.

headline: After reading this years comments, affirmation of my last year and half on the job.  So glad I got out of the cult
pros: Timing IS everything if you got in early you made out like a bandit here with stock options but it’s those same people who sucked this place dry and ruined it for everyone else
cons:
If you enjoy not thinking about why you’re doing something, putting an effort in only to be told you’re effort is worthless than this if the place to be.

“Management” is better in current White House administration than at Indeed.  People will only have your back if you came up with them in the ranks and even in the end I’ve seen a lot of underhanded moves just so someone could get a new title/a few reports under their belt.

To think I actually was excited the day I started as if I was joining something I could get behind/believe in/make a difference at.  It was at my first/last volunteering event that my eyes were wide open.  Indeed lures people I’m with their culture and their mission “to help people get jobs” yet at the end of the day that veil is very thin - you’re selling ad space.  

Back when I joined management actually tried to teach the art of selling.  Then they slowly converted all of the account managers into the beast they made us loathe - inside sales.  A year later we were all screwed - call center USA.  

Sales is an art and artist can’t be manufactured.  Consultative sales is born from relationship building.  You can’t build a relationship from logging minutes/dials and tracking busywork for the sake of tracking busywork.  What comes from that is false reality.  Your reps aren’t hitting quotas because they can’t hit something that’s arbitrary.  Your reps that are hitting are the few your managers want to keep around because they like them.  They’re their yes men/women - they’re not necessarily good sales reps.  You just need a few examples to say “see so&do did it, now why can’t all 200 of you?”

You had a model that worked graduating accounts that had matured in spend and size to account managers, then you went and put greed before everything else.  Now you’re reaping what you sowed.  

Maybe your banking that the younger the hire is the less questions they’ll ask.

Either way you allowed a few rotten eggs to soil the whole bunch.  

Perhaps when a rep says I’ve mastered my time in sales (aka I can see the forest for the trees) and I can better serve Indeed in a different capacity you actually give them a fair/equitable chance to apply within and change roles/departments?  You’ve already invested in them as an employee, oh wait! thats right because it’s still a popularity contest not a job application.

headline: Will work you to the bone , but you will learn a LOT

headline: Great work environment

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
There are so many it’s hard to keep count. The obvious free food, unlimited PTO and top class benefits are all brilliant but what makes it for me is the progression and support that is available. I started in Indeed as an account executive and within 2 years I was promoted to Team Lead and I couldn't have done that without the support from my manager and senior director.

I have read reviews around females not being promoted but in my own experience and from what I see around me that is not true. The best person will get the job and I think that is the way it should be! Unfortunately, like many other sales organizations gender imbalance is an issue but this is not an issue management are taking lightly which I think is great. There is no overnight fix for this issue but I do think with the right procedures in place things will change over time.

The job itself is very hard and when this is the case of course attrition rate will be high, however if you are up for the challenge the opportunities are endless! 

The compensation in Indeed is fantastic so the hard work is worth it. I would suggest knowing what motivates before you start this job as if it's not success, progression or money you will find it hard to keep on going.
cons:
Sometimes I feel the job can be mis-sold by the recruitment team and people don't know what they are signing up for. The correct expectations should be set from the onset! 

I dont think enough is being done by the talent attraction team to attract a diverse workforce simple activities like going to more grad fairs can help this!

headline: A Cry for Help..
pros: Amazing colleagues, amenities trump most workspaces and pay is better than most in valley (was)
cons:
The sales floor used to be a buzz of activity with celebrations and sales left and right with meaningful solutions for our clients. However, those are of the past where now is a desolate floor where you could hear a pin drop.

The senior leadership in Scottsdale and upper-management in New York have made the job a predatory landscape in a matter of 2 months. Leaving to mass firings and senior reps, and top performers leaving in a heartbeat. The push to be a Fortune 500 has left most of the company's values to the wayside.

A new product emerged within the company and it was forced upon us, the account executives, to be the BDRs for the product with an inadequate compensation structure. It's being shoved down SMBs throats with costs that are inappropriate for businesses of that size and the reps being put on plans if the numbers are not obtained. Quotas are starting to become unattainable with zero insight on how they are created although it's been asked to expose this from the reps. There are TWO CRMs being used with duplication of the same records to be inputted taking up time. The hyper-growth of hiring QoQ is starting to reflect in reps books where worked through accounts appear more and more leading to dead-ends, but same quotas expected.

In the end, the sales leg has flipped a 180 in the wrong direction in a matter of a year with a grim outlook and the lost focus on consultative selling to an aggressive sale with inappropriate solutions for our clients. Indeed will lose its upper hand if nothing is done immediately.
