headline: The place that doesn't help people keep jobs
pros: Location in the city close to trains
cons:
Directors have left, right down to account executives 
Indeed does not care nor value its employees 
You are number that has to hit a number to survive 
There are favourites that get what they want and promoted - 
Senior HR thinks there is nothing wrong with staff leaving or leaving bad reviews 
Half the team has left this year alone 
hr doesn't even know people's names!

headline: Sales Executive
pros: Work life balance is good
cons: Transparency is a current challenge

headline: Sinking ship
pros: Free snacks and unlimited annual leave
cons:
If you want to work for an organisation where micromanagement is at an all time high then this place is for you! 

If you want to be bullied and continually made to feel incompetent then apply now!

The Sydney office used to be a fantastic place to work. People were rewarded for hard work ethic and were driven to deliver outstanding results. 

Indeed globally decided to make a change and unfortunately it has come back to haunt them. Top performers have moved on as they could see the writing was on the wall. Originally i was reluctant to write a review however reading some reviews lately (which have been quite clearly been written by senior management - trust me I know) potential candidates need to know that this place is rotting at the core.  It starts at the top with a sales leader who is clueless, rude and arrogant (plus thinks it’s okay to swear at new hires) coupled with a HR team who are “yes” people and keep a blind eye to everything that is wrong with this organisation. 

Reading recent posts saying there is a buzz is in the office is laughable. The only buzz in the office is buzz kill and as mentioned is from the leaders above. This isn’t a good place to work nor will you see any sort of progression. If you want your sales career to stall and watch as Seek continually dominate the market then this place is definitely where you want to be. Senior Management, HR and Marketing are all rudderless and watching the world crumble around them and with attrition at an all time, they have no idea how to fix it (besides write positive posts on Glassdoor who are Owned by Indeed mind you).

If you really are that desperate for a job then be my guest otherwise stay well well clear of this incompetent organisation

headline: Don't waste your time
pros:
Health care
Catered breakfast daily/lunch on Wednesday
Leave at 4pm each Friday/drinks in the office
Great parties (Xmas etc)
Unlimited PTO (but this doesn't really exist for sales)
Snacks
cons:
If you want a soul-less job, then this is the perfect place for you. Once upon a time, Indeed was a great place to work, then it went downhill in the past year. Here are the reasons why:
1. You work so hard to get in big deals across the line, only for the model itself to not allow you to reap the rewards.
2. Commission,  forget it - you work hard to walk away with peanuts
3. The culture of the office is in shambles, no music, no talking to each other,  if you are in the kitchen making tea for more than 2 minutes, you will get questioned
4.  Incentives are fun but not when you  land a big deal and your reward is to high-five your team mates
5.  No leadership from management
6.  Senior leaders that swear at reps and use vile language, don't get reprimanded
7. A lot of school yard bullying
8. HR want you to address thing with them.. they probably only want to do that so they can gage what head count they need for all the unhappy reps that are thinking of leaving.

The list goes on....  

One thing is for sure, you will make the business money, but in the end you won't get rewarded. If you feel like free food and health care is for you, then by all means, this job is for you. But if you want a career and make your mark, then consider looking elsewhere as you are just going to waste your time.

Those that have left are in more successful roles, doing what they love and killing it. You can build up resilience by working here.

The positive reviews on here are  not true at all.  I read them and the only people that talk that way are managers trying to salvage what is left of the place. A lot of the negative reviews are deleted as Glassdoor is a sister company of Indeed. The negative reviews were addressed by the senior leadership team and they said that they are not inacturate. Think about it, why would someone bother to write a negative review unless there was truth to it.

headline: Tough work, good environment
pros: It's a goal oriented place which is motivating.
cons: Sometimes the work-life balance isn't steady.

headline: The negativity has gone with some bad apples... Indeed is back to business as usual
pros:
Indeed has only been amazing since I've worked here.  I've been promoted a couple of times, I've taken home some very good commission and bonus, whilst also having unlimited paid leave, catered breakfast and lunch, beers on a Friday, and a higher than average super. We play sports, we get massages, we have trivia nights, we have offsites. There's a lot of benefits.

There's been a bit of negativity so it's worth addressing... We've gone through some changes in the past year, which essentially meant a new Sales Director came in, realised we were firing at 50%, and wanted to get us to work hard and make money. He did this because he is a Sales Director and wants the best for his staff and for the company, not because he is evil, or bad at his job. This resulted in a fair few people leaving who had been along for an easy ride, who suddenly didn't like being told they had to work. It's a Sales job ... it's hard work ...  that said, I make more money than most of my friends outside of Indeed who work in sales, who also work longer hours. It really isn't bad at all.

 Long-term, this is excellent news for us, as we now have teams of people that are enjoying their jobs, enjoying sales, and being nurtured by management to improve on a daily basis.  The team culture is good, the management is now good, and the job is good. We don't have any call stats or KPIs... as long as you're tracking to your number, you're left to your own devices.
cons:
It took a bit too long to get the bad apples to leave - which had a knock-on effect on the wider team. It took us a bit of time to get to where we want to, but we're there now. 

We've gone from 40 staff to 150 staff in a short space of time, so space is tight. But rumour has it we're getting more office space, giving us much more room for activities.

headline: Why work for Indeed?
pros:
Unlimited Paid Annual Leave
Private Medical Insurance
Stocked Kitchen
Leave at 4pm on Friday, every Friday
Catered Breakfast every morning
Catered Lunch every Wednesday

and the list could go on...

Indeed Australia is an incredible place to work. Everyone is supportive and wants you to succeed.
I've worked at Indeed for 3 years and they have supported me every step of the way, on top of that I've also made friends for life. As of very recently, they have also offered to pay for my Permanent Residency, which as many will know is a very large sum of money.  There is no favouritism at Indeed, they also backdated this new benefit, and any employee who in the past year has got Permanent Residency will have their fees paid off. This has taken a huge amount of stress away from me, and let me carry on with my work and life.

Sales at Indeed is not easy but is sales ever 'easy'. Recently we have undergone a lot of change, new products, new management, and a lot of unhappy employees leaving the business.

Is this a bad thing, in short, no. People do not like change, and will always focus on the path of least resistance. Unhappy, and more often than not the lowest performing sales people leave the business. 

The good news is, this opens up opportunities, and invites a whole new positive outlook within the Indeed sales team.
cons:
At this moment in time, I can't actually think of many cons.

If you don't want to get out of bed, pick up the phone, and makes sales. Then Indeed really is not for you.

headline: The product was bad and hence shutdown. Team members were supposed to interview for other teams or lose job
pros:
Work life balance

The other teams are good
cons: Gym and other facilities like in house doctor not available

headline: Sales
pros: Great perks. Great people.  Social events.
cons:
Lack of methodology in trying to achieve aggressive sales targets. Being ambitious is healthy, however if reps (especially new reps) aren't given the necessary skills and knowledge from the top down in how to try and achieve these targets, everybody loses. This is evident in the quantitive sales performance vs targets for reps across the board. Asking for extra help actually shoots you in the foot because it will be used as ammunition later down the track. A lot of irony in the sense of being micromanaged about some aspects such as KPIs for it to later be abolished due to the realisation of its ineffectiveness.  Also, there was sometimes a feeling of inconsistent metrics that reps were judged upon - nothing was ever good enough!

How can reps have confidence in management if management doesn't have confidence in them!

headline: Account executive
pros: Good location, good perks, many good people
cons:
Structure in emerging markets is a bit messy. Management care about KPIs more than growth
Too many incompetent manager and employees

headline: It was ok
pros:
Benefits were amazing - breakfast, lunch, snacks, healthcare
Great tech
Local IT team
cons:
Global company with not much understanding of local market 
Inconsistent policies

headline: 4 months of paternity leave! How amazing is that!
pros: So many to list but the best has got to be the 4 months of paternity leave at 100% pay. Many jobs offer 6 weeks, maybe 3 months.... but Indeed offers 4 months if deemed the primary caretaker. #amazing
cons: No cons. I knew what the expectations of the role were and have delivered.

headline: becoming a serious player in tech
pros: really smart people,  good pay, great perks, exciting space, investing in disruptive tech, strong senior leadership
cons: hiring a lot of middle managers who are ineffective and slow things down unnecessarily

headline: Sales
pros:
Very friendly and supportive team
Promote a healthy lifestyle by providing a kitchen full of healthy snacks, breakfast provided everyday and lunch on Wednesdays
The APAC sales trainer is absolutely amazing!
MediBank
cons:
Indeed are losing valuable employees due to their upper managements poor decisions and lack of management skills. Indeed is a great place to work if you don't work within Sales, they set unrealistic targets and regardless of whether or not you are always giving your 110% best they diminish your confidence by saying your not good enough. I have never felt so depressed waking up for work in the morning and knowing I work at a company who doesn't give a crap about how much effort you put in as an individual. 

You have no sense of job security here unless you are smashing your unrealistic which even the best reps could not hit. The commissions are nothing put a few penny's here and there - I made much more at my previous job and I was on a much lower wage base. 

Forget the unlimited annual leave if you are in sales, managers recommend not taking a holiday for more then 2-3 weeks otherwise you will fall behind on making your unrealistic target and again diminish you. 

The way they approach you in your one to one meetings is disgusting, and when your approach HR about the situation they give you a bias opinion because they are friends with the manager and give you little to no advice about how to tell with the situation instead they make things worse and tell you that maybe your aren't good enough. So much for being a supportive company!

Management are so focused on unrealistic things that they forget to actually care about their employees, this is probably why they have a big turnover rate and need to hire fresh new graduates because they are loosing valuable employees.

Let's me just say working at Indeed was the worst decision I have made, the only thing I miss is the team and how great the culture was with them!

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Pay, benefits, culture, food, and coworkers
cons: Work life balance is not great

headline: Do not believe what they say
pros: Free snacks, free shirts, that's about it
cons: Management, work-life balance, no training program, lack of support, commissions target unrealistic, negative pressure

headline: Indeed dublin
pros: Great benefits, Nice offices, Amazing people
cons: Internal politics can often lead to misdirection for actual strategies

headline: Nice place
pros: Food, coworker, office, whether, culture
cons: Salary, promotion, tool, tool, tool

headline: good environment
pros: there are many good good engineer
cons: difficult work on software engineering

headline: Micromanaged, Overcrowded
pros: Perks like free food, drinks, snacks. Progressive and diverse.
cons: Leadership bullied and micromanaged the team. Hours were not flexible. Culture was strict and stiff. Limited room for growth and mobility within this team.

headline: Senior Account Executive
pros:
I like working for a company that's a challenger in the Australian market. Indeed has an abundance of opportunities if you work hard for it. Whether that's in the Sydney office or one of our 60 offices globally. 

1) Unlimited paid holiday is something my friends are certainly very jealous of!

2) I love my team and it makes a big difference. Everyone's inclusive and works together to support each other. 

3) Free breakfast, a lot of snacks, coffee, catered lunch on a Wednesday and Friday drinks! 

4) Training never stops we have weekly training sessions, external sales kickoffs, and mentoring programmes. 

5) We have multiple programmes that Indeed encourages you to get involved with. Job Squad, Employee Ambassadors programmes, LGBTI , Women at Indeed and many more!
cons: Salaries could be higher! But the bonuses have healthy accelerators after 100%

headline: So much potential... but....meh
pros: Indeed is a lot of things. Coming out of college, it was a perfect place to start. Everything about Indeed attracts recent grads - “unlimited “ PTO, happy hours, lax dress codes and plenty of socializing. It has incredible training and they do invest a lot in their new employees. They have snacks at all times, Friday has beer at wrap up, etc. I wouldn’t change this being my first job for the world.
cons:
That being said, the real problem comes after 1 - 1.5 years of employment. The shininess of Indeed and all it’s perks goes away, and you see that it is a bandaid solution to keep their employees happy. Indeed has become a churn and burn type of place. Senior management has NO idea how bad the morale on the ground is. Most of the sales job (especially with a closed book in growth) is complete luck. I know amazing reps who had no chance of hitting due to their books and people who are new hires pacing to 150%. These discrepancies are very well known, but nothing is ever done about it. If your book is trash, youre just screwed.

Management is THE DEFINITION of micromanagement. Managers don’t care about how much you close, they care about the KPI’s they need to report up to their bosses. If you ask for help or say a problem, there is no solution other than to make more dials. That “unlimited” PTO is a wash for sales. You will be guilted any time you need to take time off, whether it is for sickness, vacation, or safety. Last snow storm, everyone got sent home BUT sales. Sales was pressured to stay by their directors, and it took all of us HOURS to get home and many got in car accidents.

My biggest issue in general is career pathing. There is NO clear career pathing and an absurd lack of opportunity to move up. You become a Senior Account Manager based on quota attainment, but then there is nothing - and forget about any forward movement if you aren’t a straight white male in the direct employer segment. In Stamford, there is not ONE female director or team lead in the DE-ACQ segment. In DE-growth, there is not ONE team lead that is not a straight white male. Out of 14 teams, there are TWO female directors who came from Account Management. This is 100% an old boys club so good luck moving up if you aren’t an aggressive man with a wolf of wall street attitude in which you want to work your team to the bone. 

Look, it’s not all bad. I met amazing people. My personal bosses were incredible people who respected me and coached me to become the sales person I am today. I made lifelong friends. The training was amazing! But in the long run, it is not worth the consistent stress and obvious favoritism. In the end, all you are as a sales person is a replaceable cog in a corporate machine. 

To all the Sales people working there - don't drink the koolaid. You WILL make more money outside of Indeed. It is NOT the best opportunity you have. And honestly, after the reorg, the money wasn't that good anyway unless you blew it out in ACQ.

headline: Glory days are over.
pros:
Lunch, Medibank, happy hours.  
I'd recommend working here, as long as you're not in the sales team.
cons:
I absolutely loved indeed it was the best job for years, unfortunately Indeed made a poor decision jumping to a sales model built for established markets within a very new market. 
My salary and earning potential was cut in half after the change and there was nothing left for me. 
International HR suggested we should have spoken to HR before leaving to voice concerns, I had three separate meetings with HR regarding a particular issue however absolutely nothing was done. The HR team is incompetent. 
Upper management is delusional, and managers and sales reps are left to suffer their poor choices.

headline: Good company to work for
pros:
-Great work/life balance
-Good compensation
-Easy enough product to sell, people know Indeed
-Awesome coworkers
cons:
-Difficult(unclear) management/ advancement path
-Office politics 
-Many managers with poor leadership skills. (A great salesperson is not innately a great leader of salespeople).

headline: Finance
pros: Everyone is really kind and hardworking here, lots of benefits and perks. I really enjoy the office space and work.
cons: Worried I'll gain weight because of the free snacks

headline: Account Executive
pros: Flexible hours and good benefits.
cons: For a company whose foundation is based on hiring, you’d expect the highest level of integrity and professionalism for Indeed.  This, unfortunately, isn’t the case from Indeed Australia. Misconceptions of growth (in the AU market) and books of business with opportunity are all bogus onboarding tactics.  It’s evident that unqualified staff have been placed in directorial roles.  As a result, leadership is incompetent, inexperienced and negligent in their responsibilities, preferring to blame their own staff for their shortcomings.  This leads to a lack of future vision, organization, and structure, not to mention an extremely toxic work environment.  I would not recommend working at Indeed AU because of the distrust and lying from management, an incapable HR team, and an unrelenting negative environment.

headline: Disappointing
pros:
Lunch on Wednesday
Breakfast Daily
Snacks
Health Insurance
cons:
Disappointing, I use to love coming into work everyday, and always bragged to my mates about what an awesome company Indeed was, and how lucky I was to work there.

Recently, majority of the sales people who added real value to the sales teams, have left. Majority of them taught me how to pitch and be successful in the role. I am aware that none of them wanted to leave, however because of the terrible pay(below market standards) and poor culture they had no choice. 

Feedback: HR ask us to provide feedback constantly, however when questioned about some of the recent resignations and poor conditions in which we are working, it is simple brushed off. In all my years of working in sales in Australia, they are by far the most inexperience/incompetent HR team, I have worked with.


Senior management expect the world from you, when no one is earning comms or a bonus. Everyone is trying as hard as they can but the targets/expectations are unrealistic for this market. Whats worst, is you have people who use to be proud to say they worked here, leaving the company with a very bad outlook of Indeed.

 I myself, have started looking and I know many others have too.

headline: Employee Morale in the Negatives
pros: Snacks, work life balance, labtop
cons: I have worked at indeed for a year and a half. Things were amazing when I first started. I saw a bright future for myself here at indeed to expand on my current skills and to learn new sales, and business skills.  But then…things took a turn at the end of 2018, headed into 2019…. Reps at indeed will no longer hit green BREAKING NEWS! I have create da lifestyle around the pay structure I was used to. That lifestyle is now gone. I find it hard to manage my lifestyle, take care of my family, and take PTO. I had planned on building my career here at indeed and now I feel as if I am “sticking it out”I feel discouraged, and ashamed coming into work everyday. The morale in the office is beyond down, and it is somehow the reps fault? How does upper management except reps to hit targets that do not even mathematically even make sense to hit due to the current spenders, and new spenders coming in. We are being set up for failure. They are better off letting people go, or being transparent in what is going on within the organization so that we CAN be positive and have a better hope for tomorrow.

headline: Account Executive
pros: snacks, environment, location, laptop, people
cons: I was beyond excited to start my career here at indeed, to learn, to grow as a young sales professional. Things were amazing my first 2 quarters....and then...things took a turn for the worst. I understand organizations go through changes, which is fine and normal. However it is wrong to make the employees who are bringing in the revenue to feel as if they are not adequate enough, rather than being transparent and providing the proper resources to be successful. Being told to stay positive can only work for so long when people have bills to pay, families to take care of, and lifestyles to maintain that were maintainable prior to all of these negative changes. Management is told to tell us to stay positive i understand the directors are just as stressed and overwhelmed as we are but, when the head of Canadian Sales, tells us to stay positive, and work harder, with no resources behind anything and no promise for a better tomorrow it makes it seem impossible and like we have no other option but to leave and use our skills elsewhere. MAYBE 5% of reps will hit moving forwards both in growth and acquisition, we are not given the proper leads, nor resources to be able to generate the required revenue per rep. And are still expected to stay positive and work hard to attempt to finish and end a race...that is un finish-able and un win-able . Some of the BEST reps at indeed have left the company 10+ within the last 30 days. But lets stay positive right? Lets keep pushing to hit our quotas that will not be reached right? unlimited PTO? yea right you wont ever be pacing to do so. I feel discouraged every single day coming into work.

headline: Amazing set up, and really relaxed friendly atmosphere.
pros: I'm here about a year, and everyone is incredibly friendly. Very supportive, relaxed fun atmosphere,  and your workload is very manageable.
cons: You are stretched, but in a good way.

headline: Passionate company!
pros: Passionate people, opportunities to learn,  work/life balance.
cons: More and more employee coming in, challenging management.

headline: No sadder thing in life than wasted talent
pros: Good benefits, free food, no work off hours.
cons: It’s a shame to see the decline in morale and employee quality over the last couple of years. The sales pit used to be full of energy and talent, now it’s full of misery and mediocrity.  Quotas are a joke, products are poorly rolled out and the lack of communication between departments is glaring.  There are far too many undeserving people in management and executive positions who have stifled growth and innovation due to their lack of vision and unwarranted egos.  “Success” has become based on sheer luck, not talent and effort.  Juice is not worth the squeeze for anyone who has aspirations of being fulfilled at work outside of a continually dwindling pay check.

headline: All Good For Me
pros:
A growing culture 
Great office 
Snacks 
Extra Super 

Mostly its a business going through a lot a change, if you want to learn some genuine business skills, this is the place for you. 

It's not an easy ride but if you try and apply what you can learn here, you're miles in front of your peers are more well-established brands.
cons: If you don't like personal accountability, you won't like it.

headline: False Hope
pros:
Unlimited PTO
Cool office spaces
Snacks
Happy hours
cons: At Indeed you start your career off with so much hope. After months and even years of hard work, you eventually start to notice that you are not getting compensated fairly, you are no longer learning and just continue to get frustrated with your lack of growth and mobility. You will soon realize that in order to advance in your career and to truly be happy again you need to say goodbye to indeed.

headline: Current Employee within HR
pros:
Company actually delivers on the culture it promises - office is bright, spacious, fun - with lots of events. Vibe is casual and friendly 
Office team are amazing - always happy, always supportive.... they work so hard 
Flexibility and work life balance, I have a young family and I have a great balance of Working from home and flexible hours when needed,  never an issue . 
Progression or change of role - as we grow we invest heavily in internal mobility of teams so great opportunities to move up or sideways 
Money!!! salaries and benefits are great :)
cons: None at the moment

headline: Nice internship
pros: A lot of good food
cons: No cons, it was perfect

headline: Best experience so far
pros: Great people, great environment, great career progression opportunities. Recognition culture based on performance and efforts.
cons: None so far. I have been happy with my journey and progression.

headline: Great Place to work!
pros: Free food and great benefits
cons: No dinner at the SF office :(

headline: Poor changes and poor leadership
pros:
The benefits I can’t fault, they’re great.
Unlimited holiday
Free meals
Good OTE
cons: Horrific range of basic pay across the sales floors. You have lower level colleagues on higher basics than senior sales roles and in some cases higher basics than the directors which makes no sense and those people on higher are not great. They seem to hire almost anyone just to make the numbers up. Growth was rapid and great for the business but managed poorly. Most people now just feel like a number where as before it had that family feel. Senior leadership are pretty clueless.

headline: Nice facilities, market leading software
pros: £££, Facilities, People, £££, Breakfasts
cons: Management decisions not communicated in relation to targets, salaries, development.

headline: Rubbish
pros:
- There aren't any. 
- Inflexible hours 
- Structure of teams doesn't make sense
cons: - Get out while you can

headline: TERRIBLE-TOXIC
pros:
Lunches on Wednesday
Healthcare
Daily breakfast 
Early finish on Fridays
Unlimited leave( limited tho)
cons:
Indeed AU has so much potential, however the people with authority, who are responsible to "stir the ship" in the right direction- are most definitely stirring it in the wrong direction. Due to the recent management changes, every thing has gone down hill. Staff who have been here for years, are leaving. 
 
Everyone who is still working there, is interviewing for a new role, everyone wants out. People go to HR with their concerns, and nothing gets done. Where do you go? If HR, is in support of the unorthodox practices. People on the team , have been publicly shamed in "all office" meetings, and there were no repercussions for the person, responsible for this. Very toxic, unsafe culture.

headline: Sydney office going downhill fast
pros:
A lot of amazing people across the Sydney office, you really do make friends for life at this company, this is the best thing you get out of working here. 

Health insurance, good super contributions.

Money was great in the first couple years.

There is one great director in the Sydney office, he was the first Dradis director there. He brought a lot of culture and atmosphere to the place, expanding the team from 6 to 20 people before the restructure. He somehow managed to give support to all 20 of us, which still amazes me. Best manager I’ve ever worked for, he supports his team and is always finding new ways to help them. Something you don’t find in most managers. He really goes above and beyond. If there is a reason people have chosen to stay, it is because of this director. 

There are other directors that are great and look out for their teams as well.

Free lunch on Wednesdays and breakfast every morning, free snacks in the kitchen as well (this has been quite helpful in saving money as most people experienced a 15k-70k decrease in earnings once the restructure happened). People are saving Wednesday lunch for dinner, and breakfasts items for lunch, as apparently they can’t afford to buy their own food on their salaries now.
cons:
Unlimited PTO- a myth, if you’re in the Sales sector of the business, you’re dreaming if you think this is happening for you.

For the past year, since the structure change, the sales side of the business, particularly growth, has been hit quite hard. Acquisition hasn’t been quite as bad, but many reps even on that side experience if they have done quite well one quarter, the next quarter their target is made to be unachievable. You have reps that are typically top performers that are at the bottom of the sales dashboard. 

If you are thinking about doing sales here, make sure you are going into acquisition and not growth (you’ve been warned). Acquisition still gets commission and bonus. Growth does not get commission, only bonus (and has to hit a higher threshold than acquisition to get a bonus). With unachievable targets, most growth reps are pretty much stuck on low base salaries at the moment. 

On top of the structure change that never made sense for the Australian market, there is an upper management team that has a poor attitude. Upper management finds it appropriate to swear at staff in front of a whole Monday morning meeting, which brings me to HR. 

HR seems to be biased, as they never asked upper management to apologize to the sales floor after that swearing incident- which would be considered bullying and intimidation (based on the bullying and harassment training they have staff complete yearly).

The mental health of employees is at risk at this place, since the change to the new structure, and new management in the last year, a lot of sales reps have spoken about the anxiety they are experiencing. These are people that have never had anxiety before working here. 

To top everything off, the culture is gone in most sales teams. A place that was once vibrant and a place that people loved to come to everyday, now resembles a silent ghost town. Apparently light music on the sales floor wasn’t a “winning culture”, but now with the silence on the floor, it is more of a “losing culture”.

headline: Love the job but something’s got to change.
pros: Great pay and culture org. wide.
cons:
Sales feels isolated from the rest of the org. and our concerns as sales people are really glossed over and not addressed head on.

Upward advancement is far and few between.

headline: Indeed high school
pros: Breakfast and Lunch and great parties.
cons: Crazy company with no comercial structure. Just call and get kpis. Very poor management. Indeed close to highschool

headline: One of the Best
pros: Unlimited PTO,  flexible insurance plans, maternity/paternity leave, free food and snacks, work from home capabilities, inclusion groups, career development opportunities, growth opportunities, collaboration, active and visible leadership staff.
cons: No "cons" at this time.

headline: The Glory Days are Over
pros:
-Unlimited Snacks
-Great People 
-Great free lunches on Mondays
cons:
I have never been at a company that has experienced such a sudden shift in employee morale. They obviously thought we were making too much money and significantly increased our quotas to the point where less than 5% of reps are going to hit target. I know so many people that are looking elsewhere. I would not recommend working here. The most frustrating part is all we're told from leadership is to stay positive. How can they expect us to stay positive and care when a large percentage of people aren't even going to get a bonus which is the majority of our compensation?

This job was always boring, but we put up with it because of the pay. Now the pay is gone, this is a terrible place to work.

headline: Could not ask for anymore from this company.....
pros:
- Things change regularly so it keeps work interesting
- Stunning office space down in our new capital Dock office
- Great benefits (Unlimited holidays and flexible working are my favorites)
- Trusted to do your work with being micromanaged
- Literally the friendliest group of people I've ever worked for
- Internal comms is getting better  and better all the time so we know what our leadership team is up to and what positive changes they're making globally
cons: - None at the moment. You have to be willing to be adaptable to work here as things do change from month to month.

headline: Nice benefits but not a nice place to work
pros: Food/happy hour, nice staff, good location
cons:
*Culture of fear
*Favouritism 
*Incompetent management
*Product that works but explanations of how it works very vague

headline: Good benifits
pros: Fun company great bennfits and training
cons: Recent unrealistic sales goals

headline: The culture doesn’t exist anymore here
pros:
Benefits
People
Drinks on Friday 
Early finish on Friday 
Brekky
cons: The company is doing a great job at recruiting new people but they clearly do not care about the retention of employees. So many valuable employees have left the company in the last 12 months and it doesn’t seem to bother upper management at all. It is impossible to get promoted, the last promotion was given more than one year ago. Management has no idea how targets are calculated, in fact if you do well one quarter, be ready to earn no comms on the next one. You are treated like kids with zero trust on time management and on the actual job

headline: Account Executive
pros:
Catered Lunches and Breakfasts.
Fully stocked fridge with snacks and pop.
Good sales training - Insights Colour Training, Dale Carnegie
cons:
If you're interviewing with Indeed ask how many of the account reps actually will/did make a quarterly bonus for Q1 2019 -  

They increased the target so high again this quarter that 75%+ of the sales reps are NOT going to hit their quarterly bonus. 

So basically, just your base pay and free snacks to live on!

The job is a bit basic.

headline: Wouldn't recommend to a friend
pros: The people are great for the most part.
cons: This is a test department and the department needs to figure some things out. The turnover rate is extremely high in this department, most likely because they don't pay the employees well for bringing in millions of dollars per quarter!

headline: Systems don't work
pros: Work-life balance and workplace environment.
cons: No one oversees operations. Departments fight with one another over projects, data systems don't sync, salesforce.com doesn't work, new product reporting is laughable.

headline: Great place to grow your career.
pros: Strong growth structure within the company.
cons: Very departmental, meaning your experience there will be determined by which team you are on. Most teams are strong, but no company is perfect.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Bustling sales floor, always buzzing
Great earning potential
Linear growth opportunities
cons: Not a con, but you have to be willing to graft

headline: Worst place I've ever worked! Don't let them trick you.
pros: The only good things about this place is their snacks. You can't slap a free snack on a job and expect the culture to immediately improve, though.
cons: Everything else! This place is run like an old-world mob-style gang. Say one things wrong, push back on one thing, share one new idea and you will be forever marked. They will do everything in heir power to get you out because you don't believe in the "Indeed Way." Additionally, the product doesn't work as well as other job boards and I heard one of their top developers share that openly. This is the worst place I've ever worked and dreaded every moment after training.

headline: Best job
pros: Everything is great here
cons: nothing bad yet at the company

headline: Rubbish pay!
pros: great people and culture! Free food and dress down
cons: favouritism, don't have policies in place, no recognition for hard work

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
> Great salary and benefits
> Relaxed work environment with flexible scheduling
> Gourmet cafeteria and coffee bar
> Lots of opportunities to learn and grow
cons: > Parking is a bit of a disaster at the Champions Grandview Pkwy location

headline: Great company and environment to work in, some growing pains
pros:
- 100-140k OTE for SAE, 
- challenging environment with room for significant personal and professional development
- I work as an senior account exec within the growth segment of the business. I see passionate management team handling a period of rapid growth as well as possible. 
- pension
- the usual office perks etc..
- possible to take 30+ days off if u get ahead of your number
cons:
- growing pains all over the place but accepting these are going to be there with a positive mentality towards helping yourself, your team mates and your clients grow will stand you in good stead
- the inevitably poorly set up accounts that come up from acquisition every quarter add to our effective growth rate. Hold these accounts and their churn in escrow for one quarter
- confusion over new products that seem to be rolled out before they are ready

headline: Great Company
pros: Awesome work/life balance, strong management
cons: Salary could be better and sometimes feels like you're stuck in college

headline: Good & Bad
pros: Great company culture. Unlimited PTO. Good pay. Beautiful offices.
cons:
Sales culture doesn't match the company
Badly needs new CRM
Middle management was promoted from within and has insider culture
Very difficult to move up in sales org

headline: Reality at Indeed
pros:
- breakfast
- fun colleagues
- nice working space
cons:
- targets are way too high, doesn't matter what team you're in, you will be happy if you receive a bit of your bonus
- a lot of pressure from directors
- it's never enough
- people coming in on different basic salaries that are totally not fair towards employees working in Indeed for a longer time
- unlimited PTO? don't think about it, it's all in the hands of your director and sometimes totally not fair
- a lot of software bugs
- some teams really mess with clients and give them wrong advise to get the revenue, can't blame them since the targets are high, but unfortunately they get away with it

headline: Great Company
pros: There are too many to list
cons: Very few and far between

headline: Environment Not For Me
pros: Nice benefits and Personal Time Off
cons:
Not very understanding
Manager wasn't approachable

headline: Transparent Review
pros:
Working at Indeed is truly a great experience with a wealth of knowledge to be learned. 
Indeed is willing to invest the time into you in order to see you succeed.
Sales goals are attainable however in the growth org it's difficult to grow a book as large as Indeed believes you should.
Office snacks and drinks breakfast every day and lunch once a week.
cons:
Indeed is run as an organization that grew too fast and now management goes by ridiculous metrics to measure their staff instead of what really matters.
Ex. 
Person on a sales team can spend all day talking to clients about things other than closing business and selling and gets celebrated for the amount of time on the phone as opposed to the context of what was being discussed. Whereas someone else can close business in a short amount of time and it gets glossed over because it didn't take an hour and a half to close business.
- Indeed comes up with sales goals for its team without an understanding of what a book of business can actually do and you get yelled at for an account that stops spending although Indeed is non contractual and a 100K spender can choose not to spend the next day.
- Sales teams are measured by number of calls made in a day and anywhere from 60-80 calls are expected and then the same sales teams are asked to do a ton of other work.
- Indeed is lying to itself if it thinks this level of management is sustainable.
- It feels like Indeed's culture has shifted from a fun energetic and for lack of a better word real place to being a factory workforce with robots to drill out phone calls and pray to God their quota doesn't get blown out of the water.

headline: Thorough Review of Sales at Indeed
pros: I met some amazing people at Indeed who have truly become my best friends. The benefits are great, they do care about most of their employees. Although they’ve cut back since, the happy hours were generally fun. They keep doing office renovations which are a nice touch. The sales top gun trip was extremely well done at least when I went. I’ve heard they cut back on budget a little since but that’ll happen as a company grows. Fortune 1000 company now so the product is certainly working. Even though they took away commission for most sales roles, you can still earn pretty decent money for an early-in-career sale role. The product is good and is arguably the best in the talent acquisition space.
cons: Nowadays in sales at Indeed you are just a number. The most metrics driven company I’ve ever been a part of or heard about. Depending on your department you’re either required to make 60 or 75 calls a day. Don’t worry though, everyone fakes calls in order to do this and the managers know. Most managers will micro-manage you and be on you about metrics like calls, demos, emails, notes, etc. The product is great like I said above but the talent acquisition space is very crowded and the barriers to  entry are extremely low. Competitors undercut Indeed all the time and for a lot of job postings, any source will work. Indeed’s model is cost per click, sounds great in theory but nobody knows how their flagship bid optimized product works so it’s tough to explain to clients who really want to know. Also, there are no contracts at Indeed so you can sell a huge deal and they can turn off the next day, happens all the time. Also clients will churn because the product works and they make all their hires which also sucks. Turnover was abundant mainly because Indeed hires some really suspect sales people in my opinion.

headline: Account Execuitve
pros: The culture at Indeed is great only for the people.  You meet some great people.
cons:
-No growth turning into a call center
-no transparency
-don't ask for feedback

headline: Love the Work Life Balance
pros:
Indeed truly believes in work / life balance. During your interview, get your manager's take on working from home, as every manager has the autonomy to operate differently. 
The pay is great and it has all of the benefits of a tech company (ie. tons of free food, big events with open bar and catering, very inclusive culture, flexible schedule, no dress code,  couches/ rocking chairs/ standing desk, gyms, work out classes, etc)
The health insurane is fantastic. My husband is a veteran and works for DOD and still uses our benefits. They cover things like fertility treatments- 3 rounds of IUI & 2 rounds of IVF
They have 6 wks paid paternity leave & 4 months paid maternity leave
They have events for the family
They give you tooooons of free swag
Open PTO
Follow #insideindeed for a lot of insider pics of our events
cons: The managers have complete autonomy- which is great, if you have a good manager. It is important to get to know the manager as much as possible during the interview and find out their style. Most managers are completely lax on work from home/ flexible schedules/ time off, etc. There are some that are a bit more micromanagers. Also, some products are managed extremely different than the bulk of indeed. It's important to talk to those who are in the role and really find out what they enjoy and ask the questions about work from home policies, etc.

headline: Account Specialist
pros: Unlimited PTO and work from home
cons: Management is not always qualified. Favorites are promoted

headline: Hiring Specialist
pros: Learn a lot and meet some great people. Room to develop specific skills
cons: Management needs some work lots of indecisiveness, but it is a start up. Energy coming into work sometimes felt very hostile. They promote this fun work environment but it really was not practiced in the workplace at all. Everyone felt like they could not even say hi to their colleagues.

headline: The best job I've had so far! I look forward to coming to work each day!
pros:
**We recently underwent major organizational changes. Clients needing help with their accounts either call, email or chat us and previously there were distinct teams to handle each type of these inquiries. Now, everyone is rotating and taking calls some days, chatting and sending emails other days. This change has made life at work more hectic, stressful and disorganized, however, this transition is brand new so many of us are still learning the new processes and procedures and management is probably still evaluating, re-evaluating, and working out the kinks as they go. I am still confident this is a great department, great team and very worthwhile job to have. There are some awesome career paths to reach for at Indeed, Client Success generally being seen as your gateway in and place to learn and get started.**

- Laid back, relaxed workplace

- Collaborative, team environment

- Helpful, approachable managers

- Awesome colleagues

- Good pay compared to companies offering similar roles

- Strong prospects for advancement after 1 year of employment

- Participating in Indeed's mission to help people get jobs 

- Snacks, drinks and food
cons:
- Change comes quick and often in the department, so if you like to have the same processes and procedures and stick with them year after year be aware that is not the case here

- There is not much age diversity, most of the department are 20-somethings

headline: Great career opportunities, constantly interesting work
pros: Great career opportunities, interesting work, compelling mission, strong leadership, amazing perks and benefits (including back-up child care), inclusive, incredible office space.
cons: Consistently fast paced work environment which requires stamina.

headline: Downtown Austin
pros:
-Amazing culture, the downtown office has great energy with our Sales and CS teams occupying two floors together
-As a member of the Client Success team, my job is made so much easier getting to work with a product that works as well as ours does, allowing us to not have to worry so much about retention and instead focus on how to help our clients grow
-Growth opportunity, in the last three years, the size of this office has more than tripled, creating a ton of options for high performers in several departments
cons: -Really nothing Indeed related, it really is an amazing place to work.  Getting in and out of downtown can be a headache, but that's about it.

headline: Amazing Company!!
pros: Absolutely loved working here, learned so much and got incredibly close with my team/colleagues
cons: No cons, had a great experience

headline: So far so good!
pros:
Unlimited PTO
Snacks and lunches provided
Flexible working hours and ability to work from home
Good working culture/co-workers
Good insurance coverage
Work we do impacts whole company, not just local or regional teams
cons:
Hours, while flexible, can be long due to teams in different time zones
Company is now in super growth mode, which can mean ambiguity and figuring out new processes from scratch very quickly

headline: Account Executive
pros:
Amazing work place culture, everyones is really friendly and helpful,
the training is spot on the trainers accommodate to your learning needs and make sure you get the best out of the training experience, 
Free breakfast every morning and hot lunches catered for on Wednesdays

Team bonding on Friday afternoons starting happy hour at 4pm where you can wind down after a week and enjoy some time with fellow team mates!

great perks and benefits, discounted private health insurance with Medibank for all employees
cons: Monthly pay is the only Con in my opinion

headline: Just another number at Indeed AU
pros:
Unlimited PTO
Catered breakfasts, lunches and happy hour 
Fully stocked refrigerator 
Healthcare
cons:
Very little career progression- their is nowhere to move unless you’re in the Sales, Marketing, HR or Client Success function. I was working in Sales and found it demotivating to know that I would never progress further in my career based on my discretionary efforts, in working my accounts. 

The focus was always on hitting your targets and management never cared how you went about it, just that you did it. 

Zero support from senior management including the HR function. 

US centric company.

Management are YES men.

headline: Great global brand, needs to get glocal
pros:
Flexibility
Working from home options
Great Benefits - health care, unlimited annual leave
cons:
Global leadership - US Centric - Business practices aren't localised to Australian  market
Limited career advancement opportunities in Australia if you aren't in Sales/Client Services functions i.e. Marketing, Finance, HR

headline: Truly impressive
pros:
This is an astonishingly nice place to work, in a company experiencing very rapid growth. My recruitment experience was speedy, thorough and allowed me to properly understand the company. In total I spoke with 8 people over the course of a month.
The onboarding is excellent. They bring all new starters across Europe to their EMEA headquarters in Dublin for a day of introductions and to give you your new MacBook Pro and to allow you to meet key colleagues.
The offices are extremely nice, the technology is very good and people work collaboratively within offices and with colleagues around the world.
Most meetings are only 30 minutes, there is a real emphasis on making good decisions using accurate data and then getting on with things.
They have good benefits, including unlimited holiday (to be negotiated with your manager).
And behind it all is a genuine mission to help everyone to find and secure a good job.
cons:
Free snacks in the kitchen have forced me to increase my willpower rather than my waistline!
Inevitably a company growing so quickly can require employees to embrace change and understand ambiguity. This is not for everyone and you have to be willing to accept that today's approach and structures will probably not be around forever.

headline: Amazing environment!
pros:
Great culture 
Mangement is excellent 
Goals are clear and consistent
cons:
There are no cons to working here

Great place to work!

headline: Pretty kewl
pros: Interesting work for the most part
cons: A bit chaotic at times

headline: Always learning
pros: Great environment with leadership placing a lot of trust in their engineers. I'm always learning because I work on challenging problem with some really talented colleagues.
cons: Indeed is still in hypergrowth mode which poses its own set of challenges like a constant need for good onboarding and mentoring.

headline: Great Company with Excellent Mission
pros: This company does what it says on the tin: helps people get jobs. You will work hard and deliver this goal in everything you do, and you will directly see the results. Most days, I go home feeling great about what I've done in the day. The Scaled Operations team will give you the autonomy you need to do your job.
cons: You will often be overworked and underpaid. Although your lead will fight for you, the Scaled Operations team under the Search Quality organization has no actual method for leveling its employees up. You may be stuck in your same position for a long time without much improvement, if any.

headline: unanimous
pros: good company, teamwork,food,friendly .growing company
cons: privacy, benefits,management should be listen to employees idea

headline: Account manager
pros: I took this job after people told me not to as they mentioned bad reviews on glassdoor. They warned me not to take the job and i was scared to be honest. I have been proven wrong. It is the most amazing company to work for. They really look after their employees from the very start. Amazing training , great environment, fun team, good product, easy to sell, good location, good pay, you get commission and bonus, gym on site, free food on Wednesday, great benefits with healthcare and more. I feel so at home. I used to work at google where the environment is amazing but indeed is so much better as there is no politics. They are moving the office ti the docs in 2019 and more benefits will be available then. Indeed all the way!
cons: i have nothing to be honest..

headline: Fast paced, great team of people to work with
pros:
- Ability to work with the latest processes, tech stack and tools.
- Each team member brings a wealth of knowledge and the overall learning is immense each day
- Autonomy in engineering teams
cons: There are no major cons, in my opinion.

headline: Call center with nice perks.
pros: Snacks, Happy Hour, benefits, colleagues. The operations team is trying the best to make people feel like a part of the company.
cons:
Management - bad managers, who love micromanaging and lying to your face,  No support or trust. Favoritism deluxe.
Product - great product overall, however a lot of bugs and little information about how it actually works so mostly you make up something to explain it to clients. 
Daily work - most boring and one dimensional sales: call, call and call more. Even if you know the client is not interested and you have nothing more to offer. If you do bad, it is your fault, never the book, lack of support etc.
Client management - we always say that we are consultants and not sales people, but accounts get reassigned so often that you can not build a trusting relationship with the client. 
Work with other departments - very bureaucratic, but people in the teams are actually nice and also struggle with their own problems like CS and finance, who have not enough people to cope with all the assignments. 
HR - never believes you or to scared to do anything. Manager who poison entire teams are kept in the company, which increase turnover rate.
Internal mobility - worst I ever encountered. They rather hire new people then give people a chance internally.  Only company I know who does not favour internal over external candidates.

headline: Content Acquisition Manager EMEA
pros: They give you a branded notepad and coffee mug on first round interview
cons:
Extremely long interview process (3 months) 6 rounds, no clarity, no interim feedback, interviewers lacked experience and understanding and were unprepared, solicited feedback from my contacts without my approval, in the end gave a meaningless and incorrect reason not to offer position.

I was buzzed to start, really looking forward to working in Indeed but that was easily the worst hiring experience of my long professional career.
Advice: Stay away

headline: Amazing comapny with good information
pros: Goood atmosphere and good management
cons: Nothing as of now. maybe ater

headline: Best place to work
pros: So many perks and benefits
cons: Too much food... If that's a thing

headline: Sales
pros: Great benefits, unlimited PTO, snacks
cons: Lower pay, work life balance is hard to maintain in sales

headline: Best career move I've made
pros: Growth opportunities, great internal mobility, promotes from within
cons: Increasing amount of red tape, compensation.

headline: No transparency at all and too much harassment
pros: Great perks. Free lunch & snacks, free beer, free gym, game room, overall a very nice office. Open PTO policy makes it easy to have a good work life balance.
cons:
Some people abuse the open PTO policy. I have seen people taking PTO every month and not getting any work done at all, but that is accepted as it's the employee's freedom to decide when and what to work on.

The managers say that it's an open and safe environment, but in reality there is no transparency and no freedom so say what you think. I was told not to point out problems unless I have a solution ready. That is the same as saying "you can't ask questions unless you have the answer." It does not feel like a safe environment when you get criticized for asking questions.

The evaluation system is not very fair, as it gets heavily influenced by the opinion of the managers. Even if the whole team gives you positive feedback, if you don't get along with one manager you will end up with a negative evaluation.

There is a problem with harassment as well. There have been sexual harassment incidents but the company failed to take any action to prevent this kind of problem from happening again. Overall it is not a safe environment to work in, especially if you are a woman.

headline: Great Company, Mad Benefits, Low pay
pros: Phenomenal company culture, passionate people, great insight into hiring world, plethora of benefits including OPEN PTO, Life Insurance Policy
cons: Low pay. The company pulled the old bait and switch tactics on we need a degree and yet first day of training suddenly, one is not required. headline: Indeed is like a well-kept secret!
pros:
-Top-tier engineering talent so you'll be working along side other smart individuals.
-You potentially get the opportunity to work with the latest and greatest technologies and solve interesting problems in regards to scalability and distributed systems.
-Fulfilling mission: Helping people all over the world get jobs.
-Great perks & benefits: Free food, drinks, and snacks all day (among other things).
-Great company culture and lots of fun events year round.
-Competitive salary.
-Currently experiencing hyper-growth with no signs of slowing down - opportunity to grow with the company and make an impact.
-Great work/life balance and unlimited PTO (and they let you use it!).
cons:
-Hyper-growth could be seen as a negative to some people who prefer smaller companies.
-Lots of growing pains to support all the growth including lots of processes changes, etc.
-Inevitable weight gain due to unlimited access to food (both healthy and unhealthy).

headline: Fast growing company
pros: Newest tech, Good Work/Life balance. Benefits kick in from day 1
cons: Company was set up by Ex-Google employees who brought those policies with them. Tough multiple interviews to get in and end up at the bottom along with all the other intellects clamouring for enough attention to get a promotion that doesn't happen unless you're a manager. Sales Dept is intense and not for the faint of heart. Other departments risk boredom setting in. Prepare to have company culture forced on you

headline: Senior Account Exective - High Growth

headline: Politics seeps throughout the engineering organization
pros:
Unlimited PTOs
Data-driven culture
Ability to drive initiatives and iterations
cons:
- Politics is seeping into the engineering culture. Your fate and growth depend on your manager and how much they know how to play it. If you don't have an idea how things work here(being an engineer), you will be manipulated until you know what the right expectations are.
- You won't be rewarded what you deserve in a direct manner. Instead, the management will torture you to yield your fullest so that you think that you really achieved it and the bar is high which in reality was not.
- Engineering bar is getting lower.

headline: Good if you are a miilenial
pros: Beautiful offices, good food, excellent health insurance.
cons:
Salaries below market, they ask that people have a master degree and years of experience for a salary in the low 60's ( and that is including bonus) , I wish Indeed spent less on happy hours and a  plethora of activities catered to provide fun to the twenty-something and start paying fairly.  Leadership is provided by people that might have vast knowledge about the company but whose only job has been at Indeed and with poor management skills, tolerance for laziness is ok because preferences towards friends are not unusual, this promotes a culture of self entitlement that makes work harder than it should be. 
Open PTO sounds like a great perk at the beginning but then one realizes that some people overuse it whereas some people use little time off, and for the latest, there is no pay for unused time when leaving.

headline: Internal management promotion is killing the org
pros:
+ Free breakfast and lunch on Wednesdays
+ Happy hour on Friday
+ Good base salary +ability to make a lot of money in sales
+ great work mates
+Pool table, Xbox, free snacks
+ The best office location in town
+ Good work / life balance
+ The perks and benefits
cons:
-90% of managers have 0 management experience and have been promoted because they are here for ages, people management is terrible
- The "unlimited PTO" that does not exist
- Targets for supposed to be fair but massive discrepancy and unable to understand why your target gets crazy one quarter
- The larger Indeed has gotten, the less transparent the management has become

headline: Tossed aside with no mentoring less than a year after being hired
pros: Stellar health plan, great perks as a remote employee (snacks delivered quarterly, start-up money to set up home office), even more perks at Austin (free breakfast, lunch, coffee bar, too much to list). Pay and bonuses are outstanding. Many great people working there.
cons:
I was subjected to the dreaded Performance Improvement Plan (PIP) after just 7 months at the company, then was let go a month later. Quarterly reviews are nice to gauge your standing, but I never realized how quickly you could be cut loose if you don't meet expectations in your first 2 quarters.

How did that happen so fast? Because my team was all about fast: speed was their primary focus; I was expected to code fast, and I simply wasn't fast enough. (Never mind the fact that I delivered almost zero bugs while I was there...) I never got an explanation as to WHY speed was so important, either. There were no deadlines, no imminent sales demos, nothing I could see that would demand such speed. As far as I could tell, it was all about being fast for fast's sake; in other words, bragging rights.

What was most upsetting was that I was a remote employee, and I had no direct management guidance or mentoring during my tenure. I was just expected to know how to do everything, and if I didn't know, learn quickly. I wasn't quick enough.

The atmosphere felt very unsafe. I didn't feel like I could fail, because the failures would simply be recorded and used against me in the next review. I didn't feel like I could ask for help because it would just highlight that I wasn't up to par with their standards. I was very much on my own, and for a remote employee, this is death; there is no chance for success.

I honestly question the monetary decision of investing so much money in hiring a software engineer only to let them go less than a year later, especially without any mentoring. Even after my managers realized I didn't know as much as they thought I did, they didn't see any reason to grow me into the role. When you make billions of dollars a year, I guess you can do that.

My advice to future Indeed software engineers: know your stuff before you sign on with Indeed. You won't last long if you think they'll help you ramp up.

My manager displayed  a narcissistic tendencies and life was very difficult around this person. No one helped me and HR made it sound like I was the problem. This person broke so many rules, did and said so many inappropriate things. I went to their manager, he did nothing, I went to HR & was also stone walled there. So I left. Stay away from this toxic employer unless you are young, white and male. or a thin white young blond woman. Everyone else will have massive difficulties. Indeed is a reflection of the worst in our society. Absolute rock bottom.

Very big disparity between Austin and Seattle offices and Engineering and HR orgs. The Indeed Engineering org has quarterly evaluation periods for employees of all levels. The Indeed HR org doesn't do quarterly evaluations for any of their employees below the senior leadership level. 

-Most Talent Attraction managers sit in Austin and have very little visibility into Seattle employees performance

-No career path for roles in Talent Attraction (recruiting)

When communication style is elaborate and culture is free of ego and filled with cooperation then obviously one would love to work with more dedication. I use to work in Hyderabad office. It was one of my best experiences in my career. If you are getting a job in Indeed then just don't miss it by too much thinking about its plus and minus, I have seen more reasons to work and more plus points to work than minus, specially wherever we work people around us with whom we work everyday are important, And trust me you will encounter true humans who really want to help you in your career growth, their mission itself is to "Help People Get Jobs", and every employee truly works towards their mission.
cons: Not much, it is still growing in India. There are enough challenges to solve. Every company learns from mistakes, I did not see any big minus point. If you want to join the company in Hyderabad or in any of the other global centers then just go ahead. Its going to be a great journey,

A lot of people have great ideas to increase efficiency but they fall on deaf ears, so it seems like there is no end to the inefficiency. The rest of the week is just meetings that don't result in much of anything and I honestly don't see the point. At best, your Team Lead will put you on a project that you spend months on that ends up going nowhere.

The pay is already on the low end for the Austin market and you can only get a very small raise once a year. The only growth opportunity is to become a Team Lead so if you don't want to manage people this is basically a dead end job.

headline: Account Executive
pros:
An honest review that should be considered before taking a role at Indeed. I value these reviews greatly and want to give an inside look for anyone considering this role. Your jobs is to make 60 cold calls and be on the phone for 100 minutes every single day. Due to these forced metrics which I think are necessary it causes tons of bs and fake dialing for all reps. There is a lot of fluff and faking demos,props, calls and even money brought in. I think Indeed is a great employer who compensates fairly and gives out a ton of free food which is nice. Making 100k is very doable and most people on the growth side are at least at that level regardless of skill. A lot of this job seems to be luck as the people you are calling know how to use the platform and just have to sit back and hope they spend. 

I think its a good role to consider and I do not regret my time there.
cons:
There are about 50 people gunning for 1 manager opening and many people have been at company a long time. I would say maybe 1% of reps actually move into management. 

Randomness in regards to who does good. The sales results is not a true result of who are the most talented sales reps as it comes with tons of luck for how your book of business performs. 

Things to note - Can you make 100k - Yes!
                                     Know you will be calling the same people over and over who don't 
                                      really need your help most of the time

Overall I think its a great first company out of school and was very helpful to have a recognizable name on the resume. 

Tons of admin work to be done for a sales position

headline: Shiny on the outside, churn on the inside
pros:
Initial impressions are very impressive. It's hard to get hired here and the first visit can give the 'wow' experience.
-Office environment is beautiful (contemporary office space, Aeron chairs, Varidesks on demand, Herman Miller furniture, etc.) Tons of really good, free food.
-Lots off employee events like happy hours, family days, picnics, etc.)
-High growth mode. Relatively easy to get a new hire req approved. Very optimistic about the future (without explanation.)
-good level of transparency about most things (salary and comp bands are not one of them)
-Product and Engineering divisions run the show
-Opportunities to move around the company
-Salary trends on the low side.
-Benefits are very good with low cost to employees.
cons:
-Feedback system gone fubar. Online system allows people to send private email to managers about their people. Creates two-face, passive aggressive environment
-Different departments have unique cultures and hierarchy (meaning some positions a different grade then equivalent positions in other departments.)
-Avoid program management and BA roles which are like department admins
-Some VPs are very tuned in (COO, CEO, Product, Eng), others are not (Marketing)
-Very millennial oriented. Abundance of perks creates entitled environment. Lack of urgency to get things done. Passivity abounds.
-Most departments use a quarterly eval process. The continuous feedback system can be helpful but is time consuming and makes people feel like they are walking on egg shells.

headline: Sr Account Executive
pros:
Nice financial compensation for an inside sales job,  great perks, insurance, benefits, and nice office. 
Great team events when we have them once a qtr....happy hours are OK
cons:
I don't even know where to begin. For starters if you CAN NOT make 70-80 calls EVERY DAY NO  then do not work here.  There's a lot at this company in Sales that is flawed behind the scenes...... 
Do not let the big brand name fool you. I know it's great working for a big name company but you need to be prepared for what the job entails.  They want an army of people. If that is not you do not work here you won't be happy because of the stress of trying to follow suit. You have an hour to hour schedule. You have task after task. They "try" to not micromanage but they will forever hover bc how they have designed their sales process to be inefficient. 

People walk around here looking stressed. People barely talk throughout the day because of all the issues in sales that burn them out.

1)CRM is archaic
2) Lead generation is archaic and completely unorganized  

The metrics are not designed to solely help you sell. They are designed to show productivity fake it until you make it productivity. It could be a lot more simple and effective. 

 Leadership does not fix issues that are ongoing, they are not willing accept people who inquire for improvements and are capable to question things to implement change.  Again, they want you to be robotic and if you can't do that you will not be happy. Indeed seems to be focused on culture, well not sales, they do not encourage culture in sales.  They do not care about budgeting for events they want you to hit your 70, 80 dials and do all the backend work in spite of how noticeable it is walking by someone and see their face burnt out. We should budget for sales to feel more connected to one another after all the hard work that only sales people understand.

headline: Great culture & growth

High growth

cons: Lack of good projects in India office

headline: Lots of potential, plagued by micromanagement
pros:
- some nice perks, especially in larger offices. Great office spaces 
- Some level of flexibility, though this was taken away gradually as the company grew
- You get to work with some great people
cons:
- blatant favoritism, promotions based on nothing but good connections to leadership and personal friendships. Leads to deeply toxic atmosphere
- Incompetent leadership in most teams - the few exceptions really stand out and I kept wondering why they stick around. Leaders are often young and inexperienced, I had the impression that no leadership training was available
- Biased, unfair and intransparent performance reviews. Don't count on your bonus, because they will even cite vaguely worded attitude issues to limit your bonus. Basically - if you are successful your goals will be lifted to impossible standards sooner or later.
- Lack of strategy. The company seems to be jumping from here to there constantly, I never saw a coherent strategy that gave me confidence that Indeed can be successful even when Google and Facebook enter the market
- Bro culture across the board, made worse by perks being more tailored to that audience, not the female or older workforce. Diversity initiatives are in place and driven by great people, but Indeed's biggest diversity issue is an extremely young, male-centric culture, with little room for parents, women, minorities (I found the review further down from a black employee’s perspective very accurate!)
- Insane micro management. I've never experienced anything even close to this. Seems to be happening across all departments. Soul-crushing. 
- No career development, especially outside of Austin and Dublin offices.
